description:
There might be new sheriff in town. 

Relatively new Rose Kitchen gives Tuyet Mai a run for their money in the Bún bò Hu battle.
author: Hanah L.

description:
"I'm for mystery, not interpretive answers.... The answer is never the answer." - The Art of Fiction 

Location: The Tenderloin District, San Francisco. 

I had a really nice, but mysterious dinner here. First, my dinner was delicious, and jasmine tea as smooth as smooth. The service (family owned & operated) was very friendly to the point that I felt they wanted to adopt me, lol. Yet even though everything was a green light I can't help notice the "mystery" I had... this mysterious place is called Tuyet Mai. 

I've been on a Asian persuasion mission this past week, dining at Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Thai restaurants, and tonight Vietnamese called Tuyet Mai. After perusing Yelp I find Tuyet Mai with solid reviews and what stood out was "family owned" and "delicious foods". I was sold to cross the safety zone and enter into Tenderloin territory, if you know, you know, and yet where most authentic Vietnamese restaurants are located. Tuyet Mai it is! 

After zigzagging the hood I find Tuyet Mai on Hyde St. & O'Farrell St., a stones throw from an Adult Theater, Liquor Store, and derelict whatever that was, yet the location on Hyde was actually calm with a good vibe. I enter with a warm "Engrish" greeting and handed the menu. Jasmine tea is served. I decide on the dry vermicelli with spring rolls & bbq pork. I then ask the Mrs. on what does "meat roll" on another dish meant. Her response was "you try it" lol. Um ok. So she makes my dinner with added "mystery meat" lol. 

The Bun Cha Gio is served pretty quickly. And I notice after a few bites of the "mystery meat" that it's some sort of sausage sliced up. Pretty good actually. My dinner was delicious with a good ratio of meats, vegetables, and vermicelli. The fish sauce was on point and allowed the combination of foods to mingle well. The jasmine tea flowed nicely. 

In the end, I recommend Tuyet Mai to all. The only caution flag is my "mystery" bill. See many come to the Tenderloin to eat "cheap" Vietnamese food. I expected the same. And why I was charged an additional $3 is a mystery indeed. It most likely was for the "mystery" meat that I only had a question on but the Mrs. added it to my plate. I guess, I had no clue I was ordering it?! Kinda like ordering a foot massage but being told to go all around the world...
author: Eric R.

description:
This is not the best meat I've had with pho, I like it a bit rare when it goes in; however this is the most authentic bowl i've had so far (pho tai) in downtown SF. The broth was pretty good, usually there's a tendency to add too much oil (and I wind up adding more with fish oil anyway) but I didn't have that issue here.

Really sweet staff and a clean place.
author: Kimberly R.

description: It's a little but nice home cook place. People who work here was eating same food as me. Makes me feel they care about their food.
author: Hana H.

description:
Tenderloin has an abundance of Vietnamese restaurants in-fact there are as many as 8 specialized Pho restaurants apart from banh mi and coffee shops. I randomly decided to try Tuyet Mai one Saturday afternoon for lunch. At the peak lunch hour, it was completely empty. This seemed a bit odd as most other Vietnamese restaurants usually have a wait at this time. Anyway, as I had already committed myself I decided to push ahead and get something. After going through the menu, I decided to get the Duck curry noodle soup ($9.30) as I had not seen this item at other Pho restaurants. I had to pay cash as I think I did not hit the minimum required for cards.

After ordering it was a long 20+ minute wait for getting the food. It seemed that the kitchen was working on a large to-go order of almost 10 servings that they had to fulfill before they could attend to my order. I got two containers, a large plastic container with the soup and another small Chinese to-go container with the noodles which was a good start as it prevented the noodles from soaking up all the broth by the time I reached home. Let's start with the good stuff. The duck noodle soup was pretty good. Even though there were no big chunks of duck meat its flavor came through pretty well. I was expecting it to be very salty but it turned out to be properly seasoned. Now for the bad. The quantity of noodles that I got was very tiny, filling about half the small to-go container. What's worse if that they were small strands that seemed to be left over from the large order. It was as if they just took all the leftover noodles from the last order and packed those off for me. This is just not done. Goes without saying that I did not like what I got.

Price-wise it was pretty cheap and inline with what you would pay at other Pho restaurants in the hood. Unfortunately, the quality of the noodles let these folks down which is a pity as the soup itself was pretty good. I'm going to attribute this to maybe a onetime thing and try them again in due course but given what I got I'm in no hurry to do that.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
I love Banh Coun and Banh Uot. Something about meat wrapped in rice flour noodles just does it for me. It's no wonder that cheong fun is my favorite dim sum dish.

Tuyet Main is one of those places that offers this dish, which is why I love making the trek through the used heroin needle-laced streets of the tenderloin to Tuyet Mai.


I don't know how any of their other dishes are.
author: Kay C.

description:
I'm in a mission to find good bun bo Hue in SF. Tin failed terribly. I recently tried this place and the lady owner told me she was from Hue. I got banh beo, which is prepared in Southern style not Hue for sure. 
Their banh khoai is interesting. It's like banh xeo but will egg and mushroom in it. 
Now the back to bun bo Hue, it's sweeter than I expected, 6-7/10 if I have to give a rating. Of course it's no where near Bun bo Hue An Nam in San Jose.
author: Vy T.

description:
Visited this place twice in a week when I found it. The food is so good! The banh xeo is crisp but not greasy, their bun bo hue actually has a ham hock in it, the mi quang is delightful, and their banh khot is perfectly balanced with the large shrimp fried inside. I also love that they have banh trang and give you heaping amounts of veggies to wrap your dishes with.  

Service is fast and friendly. Definitely a new staple restaurant for me!
author: Marlene T.

description: Came here for an early lunch before heading out of SF thus we were the first customer there. The owner was very friendly and nice. We got their Bun bo hue, porkchop and chicken. After trying all of it, I found it a bit different from the usual ones I've tried before. My guess is that the owners came from a different part of Vietnam. Overall, it was a lovely meal.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I loved this place! The food was delicious, and the lady (owner?) was soooo sweet! 

I came here with my boyfriend and we ordered 4 dishes and almost added another one. Apparently people think I could be a competitive eater. Anyway... we had bun bo hue, mi quang, #13 banh cuon(?) and banh xeo. She brought us all kinds of little plates and bowls when she realized we were sharing everything. I also had a soda xi muoi (sour plum with soda water), and it was delicious! The plum was nicely preserved and salty enough. Some places add in way too much undissolved granulated sugar, but this one was just about right! She also brought the rest of the soda water so I could keep topping it up myself. When I wanted my drink to go (didn't finish it) she even offered me more ice and a poured everything into a to go cup. 

Anyway, food was delicious, service was amazing and constant smiles, and they accept card. My belly is very satisfied. And it always feels great eating food at places where people look like they made your food with joy and love! I'll be back!!
author: Su Lin Y.

description:
I had the banh uot thit nuong (#13), which was decent, good flavor but a little skimpy.

****Beware when you pay****
I gave a $20 bill for a $10 take out and did not receive any change. I thought maybe the older lady needed to get change but after about 10m, I had to ask the younger woman. There was a very brief conversation (which I couldn't understand), but the older lady did not seem surprised or apologetic and the $10 was promptly returned. Perhaps the older woman just assumed I was leaving a 100% tip, but you probably want to just count your change.
author: Louis Y.

description:
I love Tuyet Mai so much that I consider moving to the Bay! The place is family-run and quite small with such old-fashioned 90s Vietnamese style decor but that's how you it's authentic. My friends and I were in San Francisco for only 2 days and a half and we came here twice already. It is so hard to find a decent Vietnamese restaurant in New York so we basically ate everything we could. 

The menu offers a very wide range of Vietnamese dishes from all kinds of noodle soup and rice cake to main entrees. Bun Bo Hue, Ca Kho To and Canh Chua Ca are my favorite. Ca kho to and canh chua came along so well with white rice and reminded me of my mom's food. Bun Rieu, Mi Quang, Pho Bo, Bun Mam, Chao Long...I can't even remember all the dishes we had but they were all so delicious. If you want to try something different, definitely go for Banh Beo (rice cake with dried shrimp and dipping sauce). I couldn't find any place on the East Coast that serves this delish and I was so happy to find it here. 

Cafe sua da (iced coffee with condensed milk) and Tra da chanh (iced lemon tea) were rally refreshing and tasty as well. I only wish they had all the desserts listed on the menu, which then didn't. 

I repeat you can't never go wrong with Tuyet Mai! The price is as cheap as other regular Vietnamese place and the girl, whom I assume was the owner's daughter, was so sweet and attentive to us. Moms and aunties' cooking are always the best!
author: Hannah V.

description: Their food was edible. Nothing special really. Their "spring rolls" are actually Vietnamese spring rolls (the clear ones) but you wouldn't know because their menu has no pictures. The curry was okay, but there were too many vegetables / peppers, and not enough meat. Also it tasted kinda just exactly like curry powder. The best part was the grass jelly drink, so that should tell you something.
author: Grayson K.

description: We got pho Dac Biet to go. It was bland and tasteless. Super disappointing. I don't think I'll be back anytime soon. The only redeeming item was the egg rolls.
author: Viet N.

description: So I have my good friend take me to random authentic places a couple of times a month. This is the best lunch I have had in 3-6 months. Service is great and the food was amazing. Not in the best part of town but that doesn't really bother me. Looking forward to going back.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Update:
--went here mostly to see if Google Maps reporting as Closed was accurate. Well, the previous restaurant I had visited and reviewed has changed names to Tuyet Mai.
--had the bún thit nuong that was a good sized portion for around $8.
--friendly service
author: Rich H.

description:
MMMM So when I was introduced to Tuyet Mai, I was told it could rival Bun Bo Hue An Nam in  San Jose...which, if you know BBH An Nam, you know that that was a bold concept. After having an order of the BBH, I would definitely say that it comes close to its SJ competitor and even surpasses it in other ways! The BBH here had super tender cuts of meat that could only be achieved with either high quality meat and/or good cooking method. The cha was more flavorful than I typically find in BBH. The noodles were perfect too! Very bouncy and chewy as opposed to a denser, basic noodle. I would only say that the broth at BBH An Nam is spicier and flavored with more lemongrass than this one was. 

We also had an order of the spring rolls which were HUGE. Half of an order and a small BBH was very filling for me. I personally prefer a more peanutty sauce instead of the hoisin sauce they had but I'm sure this is also the chef's preference.
author: Diane H.

description: I really really like this place. It's tiny and isn't the fanciest or the safest of neighborhoods BUT they serve a variety of fresh herbs to accompany your banh beo, banh khot and bahn xeo. The former two appetizers are not easy to come by (unless of course you make it yourself at home) I would love for more places to have available small dishes like banh it ram, bahn tran etc. Next up, Gao Kitchen in San Mateo
author: Saliem C.

description:
Every time I think I've done a thorough sweep of all the decent Vietnamese restaurants in the Tenderloin, I find another one and this one is definitely just decent, no more, no less. It's family-run, which I like very much, and the space is modestly decorated. The food itself is not the predictable selection but central Vietnamese variations that originate from the town of Hue. Now believe it or not, I've been to Hue in my travels, but I can't for the life of me, remember anything that unique about the cuisine in that area except I did take a private cooking class in nearby Hoi An from a sassy, sharp-tongued chef named Miss Vi.

I was folding that banana leaf with hospital corners, but I digress. This place focuses on Hue's clear-broth noodle soups, so I ordered one, the $8.30 bowl of  Hu Tieu Ngoc Mai with shrimp, chicken, squid, fish balls, and a whole lot of cilantro (photo: http://bit.ly/29GgtWg). It was actually a bit bland for my taste with the broth too watery to savor really. However, the complete miss for me was the $7.40 Bánh Xep, the pork pot stickers which were skimpy on filling and just a little too limp and under-cooked in texture to satisfy (photo: http://bit.ly/29FrGoW). It wasn't enough to scare me off as I have a feeling with a bit more guidance, I could have ordered more fruitfully. Otherwise I could just show them what Miss Vi taught me in the kitchen.

FOOD - 3 stars...a bit disappointing but perhaps my palate was shaped by other parts of Vietnam so as not to be more discriminating
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a modest setting
SERVICE - 3 stars...very quiet
TOTAL - 3 stars...like Hue, it's in the middle somewhere
author: Ed U.

description: Solid traditional and tasty Vietnamese food. Not many left in the SF area. Bun bo hue, chao vit long, banh xeo, bun rieu, ....mmmmmmm
author: .I I.

description:
Banh Xeo and Bun Bue Hue are my usuals here. Mi Quang is good too.
Small and friendly restaurant.
author: Larry L.

description:
Loved our food. Loved the sweet server who helped me figure it how to eat what I ordered

We arrived about 1:30 p.m. And half full and they seem to cook to order, so it's hot and fresh 

We shared the pancake which was filled with sprouts shrimp and pork. You wrap it into lettuce leafs with mint and then dip it in an amazing sauce

I ordered the vermillicilli noodles with shrimp and calamari and chicken, with a cup of chicken broth on side. I enjoyed it

The other dish was steak, gravy, French fries, an egg, and with about six slices of this great crunchy bread on the side.

Pot stickers mini crepe duck soup catfish in clay pot 

Two Vietnamese iced coffees, of course.

June 17, 2017

Number 18 20 and 80

Bahn bot loc
Banh khot 
Com ca ri ga
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Delicious food and friendly service! This little family owned restaurant is a neighborhood gem. They get busy, but they still push out food pretty quickly and the lady is super sweet. Please be kind if the service feels slow. It's just the two of them. 

I had #1 bun bo hue, but the real star is #29 bi cuon. It's fresh and the sauce that comes with it is so flavorful! They added fried shallots, lime, and toasted rice powder in it to pack some punch.

Best of all, everything is under $10 and they take credit card ($15 minimum). I'll definitely be back!
author: Nicharee S.

description:
I have tried only a basic pho, but it was done RIGHT.  Fresh ingredients and a great broth hit the spot!  

Service was very friendly, and I liked looking right into the kitchen, which was immaculate.  Tuyet Mai is in an approachable part of Tenderloin if you walk mostly on Geary.
author: Miran C.

description:
Good food!  Friendly service!  Fast service!  
Bún bò was good cause it has a little bit of everything even pork blood
author: Katherine V.

description: Cool simple place. Service ok but the worker/owner is very nice. Bun bo Hue is ok and same with the bun mam. My friend like the bun bo Hue so everyone taste bud is diff. I still preferred bun bo Hue an nam in SJ. Overall 3.5 star.
author: Christy V.

description: I love this little hole in the wall gem. The owners are so sweet, kind and hospitable. If you wait for your food to go they offer you tea while you wait. The food quality is awesome and the price is very affordable. Credit card is minimum $15 so if you come bring cash. If you want decent Vietnamese food for a good price this is the spot. Parking is near impossible and there's no wifi. Better to take public transportation. I would definitely be back again.
author: Daw M.

description:
It's been freezing in the city lately, so all I crave is hot noodle soup. Evonne T. mentioned to me before that Tuyet Mai had the best bun bo hue, so Ly I. and I went to check it out after grabbing beers and dessert at Liholiho Yacht Club. (Who says you can't have dessert before dinner?)

First thing I noticed when we got to the restaurant was how clean it was and my first thought was that the food was probably just okay. Cause you know how the saying goes... the dirtier the restaurant, the better the Vietnamese food!

We both ordered the bun bo hue ($8). When our noodle soups came out, Ly said his soup wasn't hot enough (boo). They definitely don't skimp on the meat or noodles! Although the bun bo hue was good, it wasn't the best bun bo hue ever. I've definitely had better in San Jose, but this shall do in San Francisco!

Very friendly service and super cute mom and pops restaurant. They do take credit card (win) with a $15 minimum, so if I don't have cash to eat at Pho 2000, I'll be back to try their other stuff!
author: Christine S.

description: Chicken pho is great, quality, delicious chicken pieces. Wasn't super impressed with the broth itself, and thought there was too much noodle for the amount of other stuff in the bowl, but it still definitely hit the spot. We tried one of their crepes as well. The skin was fried and really hard, filled with a lot of just bean sprouts and carrots and shrimp (which wasn't cleaned properly). I'd say it was kind of a letdown. However, the beef curry rice platter was delicious! Kind of similar to Japanese curry, and probably just mixed from a packet but it was comforting and so good mixed in with rice. I'm a huge fan!
author: Ke C.

description:
This place has been pretty empty every time I've gone. No idea why since the staff is so nice and the food is delicious! 

They have a variety of options including: stir fried noodles, noodle soups, rice dishes, and traditional viet appetizers.

I've tried the banh xeo and mi quang. Highly recommend both!

This is the only spot in SF where I've been able to find my beloved Mi Quang. For those of you who always stick to pho, live a little. There are a variety of dishes on the menu that you don't see at most viet joints. Venture outside your comfort zone and you won't regret it!

This is one of those places that I wish I came to with more people just so that I can try more dishes. Next time...

[CARD ACCEPTED]
author: Lucy N.

description:
Love this family ran hole in the wall place! This place feels super homey and traditional with the tacky xmas decorations, bright lime green walls, and asian art hung all around the restaurant. A+ for cleanliness as well. They closes at 8pm everyday and they cover the store front with boards, which makes it look like they're closed forever but they're not! 

Must order the Bun Bo Hue here and the Bun Rieu! They Bun Bo Hue isn't super spicy  so it's perfect. My bf ordered the BBQ pork w/ rice and that was very mediocre. I'd suggest sticking to their noodle soups here for it's their specialty! :)
author: Leilani Y.

description:
The banh xeo (crepe) is a little different than what I'm used to, in a great way!  What's noticeable is that the batter is extremely crispy and a little thicker which I thoroughly enjoyed.  Odd thing about it though is that they threw in a few things of green lettuce which didn't add anything to the dish, just a look of bewilderment from our faces.

Unfortunately the banh beo was NOT good, it was really mushy.  I'm not a cook so I don't know how it got that way.  Either re-heating an old dish or over-cooking it?  Sadly definitely not ordering that ever again.

I didn't care for the bun bo hue, it tasted different to me but my friend loved it.  She said it had a strong herbal/lemongrass taste, which I like but I didn't like it in this bowl.  I'll stick to getting bun bo hue in Oakland at Pho Ao Sen.

Overall, I'd come here again to try their other dishes!
author: Joanne N.

description: Still the best place in SF for Bun Bo Hue (spicy noodle soup.  The banh khot (mini crepe) is also delicious.  So glad they are back from vacation.
author: Hap H.

description:
When you just want to wear your workout clothes to dinner, don't want to be bothered to curl your hair or put on make-up, Tuyet Mai is just the place.

Their pho ga is full of dark chicken meat, ample rice noodles and is MSG free. Probably a bit bland for some taste buds, but nothing like a squeeze of lime can't fix. A small bowl is $7.40. Their beef stir fry with veggies on noodles is also a good choice. Pile on spoonfuls of chile sauce to instantly clear your sinus.

Most places in the Tenderloin are cash only, but this place takes credit cards so that's a plus. Great hole in the wall for a quickie and a cheapie -- DINNER, that is.
author: Janice C.

description: We ordered take out after a long day and eating warm delicious soup was amazing. The food here is excellent. My favorite is the beef stew with rice noodles. We ordered appetizers and everything came fresh. Their lemonade they make is so tasty! Would definitely eat here again when I'm back in the area.
author: Crystal B.

description:
How can I put this nicely other than damn, SF is not a great a place for vietnamese food?  I really wanted bun bo hue and as far as I can tell from reviews, this was the recommended place while in the city.

Located on a "poor" block, I still held great expectations as I have of course dine at many mom and pop/hole in the wall vietnamese restaurants in the past.

Food (BBH) was simply "alright."  I will definitely rather be trekking to San Jose though if I'm ever back in Norcal for vietnamese food..
author: David N.

description:
It's been a while since I discovered a hole in the wall gem in SF. Pride weekend lucky find!! 

Small, family run, super authentic Tuyet Mai surpassed my expectations. I felt like I was visiting a friend's house and was served amazing home made food by the sweetest grandma. 

The food tastes very authentic starting with their house made nuoc mam sauce to not too oily Banh Xeo. Everything tasted clean, well balanced, and cooked with care.

The place looked dirty from the outside (especially since it is in the heart of tenderloin) but the inside was surprisingly clean! 

My mom and I shared..

1. Banh Xeo (4.5 stars) -- generous portion of the crepe comes with a mountain of greens to wrap it in. Loved it. The crepe was crispy, not too oily, with perfectly cooked shrimp and pork inside. I did wish they had removed the shrimp tails, but this was a winning dish for sure

2. Bun bo hue (4.5 stars) -- great broth, even better with a little bit more chili to spice it up. It's been tough to find a good bun bo hue place since Vietnam and I'm happy to say we found one!!

3. Pork vermicelli (4 stars) -- appreciates the amount of veggies in the bowl per my request, but the pork wasn't as good as Mau's. I wish the pork was a bit more charred to exude the smoky flavor I like so much in Mau's dish. Still solid. Can't beat their homemade nuoc mam sauce

The service was outstanding. The restaurant seemed like it was family run, which I adored, and the host / server lady was just wonderful, kindly answering all my questions and requests. The kitchen fam was great as well. 

I'll definitely be back.

I love that I still get to support family owned small local businesses like this and highlight them to the community. The food was stellar and I really hope they stay open amidst all the gentrification. 

Go here Yelpers!!!
author: Michelle K.

description: My favorite BBH spot. Probably can't get BBH anywhere else this good. I always get the mini crepes too. This is a family own restaurant and the owners are so friendly. But make sure to call ahead of time because they do close on their own schedule. You wouldn't want to drive all the way to TL and be disappointed.
author: Cori N.

description: The banh Beo and banh ut was delicious. The bun rieu was kind of disappointing, the taste wasn't there and no shrimp paste?! Meh. My husband had the bun bo hue and it was pretty good and the pho was very strong in the taste. But overall the little hole in the wall was yummy for the appetizers!
author: Lisa S.

description: Tuyet Mai is my favorite place in the neighborhood. Their food is like homemade. Like somebody's mom is cooking for you. I especially like Vietnamese mini crepes. I tried lots of things from their menu. Everything was great.
author: Simbel G.

description:
I didn't order a very exciting thing = doh! a.k.a. the Vietnamese veggie crepe was pretty boring. Inside = mostly bean sprouts, with a bit of tofu, peas, and carrots. Very one note.

I liked this place, though, and am looking forward to trying it again. Also suspect the non-veggie crepe is more exciting...
author: Shendi X.

description: Let me put it simply this way, in the city of San Francisco there's not many Vietnamese restaurants that serve this region of food that I know of. Not only are do they serve this region of food but it is so on point to the authenticity of presentation and quality that I have to say it is my favorite vitamins restaurant in the city of San Francisco. It is that good. The customer service is very simple and also very very friendly. This is a family owned restaurant that serves food that is the closest as it gets to traveling to Vietnam but you're still in the United States. On the menu I highly recommend if you like spicy food,the Bun Bo Hue. Also an item that is very traditional in Vietnam is called Banh Xeo, Vietnamese style crepe. It's a very small restaurant and it's a very small location so coming here you need to beat the lunch rush in order to sit and enjoy yourself. If you see a line it's worth the wait, if you don't see a line then you're like you're lucky. If I can give this place more than five stars I would do it, definitely highly recommend it.
author: Dang D.

description: Everyone says come here for the bun rieu or that the bun rieu is suppper authentic. Yeah, no it's not worth it. The Vietnamese food was meh. I've definitely had better. The place was also basically empty on a Friday night. Yeah....not sure if I'll come back.
author: Jenn T.

description: So so so good!!!!  This place has a huge selection and everything is delicious. The owners are friendly and make you feel as if you are dining in their home. I come here at least once a week. :-)
author: Frank E.

description:
I come to Tuyet Mai quite a bit since it's close to home, it has become my go-to place for lunch on my working from home days. I like that they're usually not super busy, and very clean, very quiet, and warm and welcoming. 

I've had their Bun Bo Hue which was very flavorful, a bit on the meatier side but still feels very light and tasty. Bun rieu is also good. I really like their Banh Xeo, it's crispy and fresh and served with lots of big lettuce leaves, the only thing I didn't like was the Banh xeo had too much pork jerky in it it was on the chewy side. I will tell them to remove the pork next time. 

I really like how their fresh veggies selection is a bit different from other pho places. They have a different selection instead of the normal basil/mint. There are other herbs that I couldn't name. Very tasty. 

The reason for 4 stars is because even though they work really well as a simple family restaurant, their food always lacks a little bit of the delicacy touch. That makes them "good but not amazing". However, they're very solid for lunch if you want simply good food and friendly service.
author: Wendy K.

description:
Came back from a festival and seriously craved flavorful soup. 
Placed an order via eat24 and picked it up in 15 minutes. 

Soup was okay, way too many noodles for the broth (which is not what i like) so thankfully since it was a to go order i only used half of it.
author: Anelya S.

description:
I've walked past this tiny hole in the wall dozens of times but have never realized that there was authentic Vietnamese cuisine hiding behind these walls!

I was coming home from the gym one day and walked down this street when the words "Banh Beo" popped out at me from the window display.

Banh Beo? I haven't been able to find that anywhere in the city yet!

Unfortunately, they don't have a vegetarian version of Banh Beo, but I noticed they have an enormous menu with over 100 items, and there is even an entire section that is vegetarian friendly!

Some options that are featured for us veg heads include:

-Pho Chay
-Various Rice dishes-Sauteed tofu & vegetables, mushrooms, etc.
-Hu Tieu Chay
-Banh Xeo Chay (Crispy yellow crepe!)
-Goi Cuon chay (Fresh Summer Rolls)

There were a few more, but I can't remember right now.

I opted for the Pho today. It was windy & cold so the warm broth would be perfect!
Unfortunately, the guy heard "Pho Tai" instead and I was served a bowl of beef pho. When I mentioned the miscommunication, he immediately apologized and they whipped me up a vegetarian bowl instead without hesitation.

The bowl of soup was fully loaded! Bok Choy, broccoli, fried tofu, cabbage, carrots! So many veggies! And of course, top it with mint, basil, bean sprouts, and jalapenos. It was a green soup machine. Yum!
I've never had a bowl of pho that wasn't a generous serving. So obviously, I was stuffed by the end of it-despite the fact that it was all vegetables.

Next time, I will have to come back to try the Banh Xeo. They are huge!
author: Lanie L.

description:
Tuyet Mai freaked me out a bit when their storefront was all boarded up a few weeks ago, but they're open again and is just as good as ever.

I'm a fan of their banh khot, which are small crispy crepes with shrimp served with a big heaping plate of herbs and lettuce to wrap them in. They're very delicious when wrapped in the herbs and dunked in the fish sauce.

Tuyet Mai has a very large menu, with lots of specialties from Hue. So far, I've tried the Bun Bo Hue, which was nice and spicy, and included a blood cube and pig's foot, and bun mam, which tasted strongly of shrimp paste. I've also tried the catfish claypot, which was also quite tasty.

Their  menu is very large, and I can't wait to try more.
author: Allen T.

description: A small fusion Vietnamese joint that is pretty cozy and small. It's nice and quiet and the food is pretty good for when you're looking to satisfy your craving. It also has some Chinese dishes which I'm not mad about. Will be going back for sure for those rainy days because it's so close to my place!
author: Grace K.

description:
I have to admit that Tuyet Mai offers an impressive variety of Vietnamese dishes that I normally don't see at most Vietnamese restaurants. Craving my favorite Viet noodle soup, bun rieu, my boyfriend and I decided to grab lunch here. 

Restaurant is located in the Tenderloins and is a hole-in-the-wall type of place. The door to the restaurant has peeling paint and is a little difficult to open. The restaurant reminds me of a typical nicer-than-average restaurant you would see in Vietnam. By American standards, the restaurant is pretty run down. The service was excellent and very attentive. 

We both ordered bun rieu and shared an order of egg rolls. The egg rolls came out freshly fried and with plenty of fresh lettuce to wrap it in. I'm usually picky about the nuoc cham that Vietnamese restaurants offer. The nuoc cham that came with the egg rolls was delicious and tasted just like my family's recipe. 

The bun rieu was underwhelming and bland in my opinion. I had to add fish sauce to add more flavor to my broth, which was disappointing since the broth is usually the best part. I enjoyed that the bun rieu comes with tomatoes, shrimp, crab, tofu, and pork blood, but I could have gone without the overcooked shrimp. There also was barely any crab, another disappointment. I would probably come back to try their banh xeo or banh beo, just out of curiousity.
author: Melanie H.

description: Excellent authentic family spot.  Try their signature soups and done forget to order an appetizer, they can be the best part.  Highly recommend.  Worth the walk
author: Bruce B.

description: Wonderful service and a nice little shop. However, our food tasted very sweet and I'm quite certain the sweetness comes from MSG. The bun khot was nice and fresh but our bun bo hue tasted extremely sweet, which is quite unusual for this dish. It didn't taste bad, but not good either. I probably wont come back. A shame really as I was excited to try this place for a while.
author: Alexandra T.

description:
This use to be Ngoc Mai but changed their name to Tuyet Mai. Ngoc Mai use to be a hole in the wall and a super run down Vietnamese restaurant. 
I'm glad that Ngoc Mai is technically "out" and "in" with the new - Tuyet Mai. 

I came in for the bun rieu ($8) and left with the banh beo ($6) and banh bot loc ($8) to go. The bun rieu was not the typical kind that I was use to. Maybe it is more of a hue style (northern style). However, I still enjoyed the soup very much.

I only got the banh beo (water fern cake) and banh bot loc (clear shrimp pork dumpling wrapped in banana leaf) to go. I love those two Vietnamese dishes! They are usually hard to find in SF, but can be easily found in SJ. So, when I saw it on the menu. I just had to get it! Both were decent, but I've had better. 

The service was superb. The girl who was serving me was super sweet. She was able to answer my question when I was totally confused about what was the difference between banh beo and banh bot loc. 

Totally loving the new place! Clean and new-ish! I'll be back to try the bun bo hue and other dishes.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
Yummmicious, need I say more?

PS. ok, a bit more.  Just that you can't find this in any other restaurant in downtown SF that I am aware of. Satisfied that little itch inside my tummy.
author: Dean N.

description:
The best bun bo hue I've ever had. Absolutely perfect for a dreary winter night. My boyfriend spent 3 months teaching in Vietnam and he claims that it's as good as it is in Hue, birth place of bbh. Bun bo hue is literally translated to noodles from Hue. His exact words were "this is just as good if not better" without all the gutter oil found in the street stalls of Vietnam.

I have to agree. The broth is flavorful -- you can taste the beef bones, shrimp paste, and lemongrass. It came with thin slices of beef, oxtail, and pig's knuckles. It even had congealed pig blood! That's as authentic as you can get. You can get a decent sized bowl for $8 and a large for $1 extra.
author: Xinxin W.

description: Duck soup (bun mang vit) was light and fresh accompanied by a delicious sauce with garlic and jalapeños. The server (part is the family) is super sweet and I heard people talking about her parents who run the kitchen. Highly recommended!
author: Brian D.

description: A great little spot for some good Vietnamese food and it's only a short walk from Union Square. I ordered the Bun ga xao xa (rice noodle bowl w/ lemongrass chicken) and my partner ordered  the Beef Broth with Vermicelli noodles and we both loved it. Great flavor. Was a perfect spot on a rainy day. The menu has a lot of variety, with many items to choose from. Our entire bill came out to $22 for lunch. A great deal. A very simple, family run place with very nice service. Definitely recommend.
author: Jen P.

description:
My bun bo hue craving drew me to try Tuyet Mai. But I also like that they also offer an array vietnamese dishes that aren't commonly offered.

Tuyet Mai is located in the heart of the TL and is literally a hole in the wall. The outside looks like a house.

We ordered the Banh Xeo and the Bun Bo Hue.

Bun Bo Hue: (3 stars) The soup was on the sweet side. Neither tangy with lemongrass nor spicy. It really resembled Pho broth to me. I really like my Bun Bo Hue with a good spicy kick to it. So I was a bit disappointed with the Bun Bo Hue. The portion was smaller than I expected too.

Banh Xeo: (4 stars) I've been discouraged from Banh Xeo because the first time I've had it, it was overly sweet and my taste buds didn't like it one bit. But the Banh Xeo here was delicious. They give you a pretty big portion and the crepe wasn't sweet at all.

I ordered the Banh Uot to go, which was my favorite dish there.

Prices are very reasonable. On average $8-$10. They do accept credit cards.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Checked this place out before a performance at the Mariner. Definitely glad that I picked this spot because I had a great experience.

Don't be too turned off by the fact that it's in the tenderloin. That's what makes this place so sick. The first thing you'll probably notice is tuyet Mai is VERY clean! 

The menu is huge and it took us a while to order stuff, but I settled on the spring rolls, banh khot, and banh boc lot.

Spring rolls
To be honest, I thought they were average compared to SoCal quality but they didn't taste too bad. I was turned off by the size (lol) and also the price too (8$ for 4??). 

Banh Loc 
I hope this is how you spell it but I thought this was a unique item to try! This wasn't what I was expecting ( I think I was expecting Banh nam) but it had a pretty good texture to it (very chewy)

Banh khot!!
Oh my, now this is what reminds me of home. The dough was very crunchy and savory and it blended nicely with the fish sauce and veggies. This is a go!

Overall, my first experience in the TL was worth. The viet food at tuyet Mai was legit, but I felt like it was a bit too pricey. That said check it out for yourself.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
I would definitely recommend this spot for Vietnamese food in SF. Like other reviews have mentioned, don't hesitate to come in even though the neighbourhood isn't the nicest.

The dish I got seemed authentic (it had pork bone, pork blood, etc) which I really enjoyed since many Asian restaurants in the states have Americanized Asian food which doesn't satisfy my palette. The prices are very reasonable with all (almost all dishes) falling well under $10. For most of the soup noodle dishes, it isn't the most filling if you don't have any side dishes, but you can easily size up to a large which was only $9.

Additionally, the workers there are extremely friendly and since it is family owned, the whole vibe of the restaurant is very homely. Definitely come here if you are craving Vietnamese food especially noodle dishes!
author: Michael M.

description:
When a relationship ends, we enter into a mourning period. What I mourn the most from my last relationship is that I will no longer have access to amazing home-cooked Vietnamese food. I got used to his father's incredibly deep and rich pho and now, I don't enjoy restaurant pho anymore. His mother is a wonderful home cook and my favorite thing that she made was banh xeo. Since the separation, I've been on a desperate hunt for great banh xeo. So desperate that I even purchased banh xeo mix and coconut milk thinking that I could somehow replicate it.

Tuyet Mai's reviews suggested that the banh xeo is one of the best items on the menu here. I was hoping for the best but prepared for the worst. The banh xeo was big, which is a plus. It was, however, really oily and I thought it was almost too crunchy. There was a good amount of pork inside but what I didn't appreciate is that the shrimp were not deveined and still had their tails attached. I don't know about you but shrimp tails in my family usually go to the dogs. The batter was on the bland side and really could've used more coconut flavor. Overall, it wasn't bad but it certainly wasn't like his mom's.
author: Yi Z.

description: great bbh! Generous portions with good broth (though might be too spicy for some). Closes at 7pm though so make sure you come on time!
author: David Y.

description: The Vietnamese mini crepe is tasty. It has a similar batter like banh xeo with a shrimp as the only topping. It's a great fix if you're craving something crispy. I like that you can eat it with your hands with the lettuce wrapping and nuoc mam. They also serve Banh bot loc, which is a see through sticky "dumpling" with meat and shrimp wrapped in banana leaves. I really like this dish and rarely see it at restaurants. Brownie points for that!
author: Mandy D.

description: i would give this place 300 stars if i could. delicious, home cooked, noms.... imperial rolls are dank af (veggie rolls are good too) and pho chay killz... sweet service and quiet ambiance with cute decor... i fux w it. QT!
author: Yves D.

description: I'm not sure who made the mistake here, but I ordered through DoorDash and the wrong order showed up.  DoorDash was not helpful because the delivery person did not want to take it back and Customer Support was unresponsive.  I called Tuyet Mai and the staff was very apologetic and went out of their way to personally help me with my issue.  They were always my favorite Vietnamese restaurant but they've gone above and beyond my expectations for service and passion.  Thank you, Tuyet Mai!  You've made us very happy tonight. :)
author: Linh T.

description:
This little gem of a Vietnamese restaurant is one of the best kept secrets in the TL. The pandan green exterior may look a bit odd being in this neighborhood but once inside, the noise of the TL circus disappears. What you've gotten left is a very nice, family run place with all warmth and hospitality. The complementary jasmine tea has a very nice and unique touch to it. 

We had the beef pho, Bun Xeo, and a the sweet and sour catfish fillet and everything was fresh tasting. The pho broth definitely has that homey-herbal taste to it, which is different but in a very nice and comforting way. The Bun Xeo is PHENOMENAL, best in SF I would say. I don't know what they put in the batter but the Bun Xeo here has a nice sweet fragrant to it. So good. The sweet and sour catfish is quite delicate and not too fishy or muddy as what one would expect.

5 stars rating for food, and for the service, the man who runs this place is so sweet and hospitable. I can't wait to go back and try other Vietnamese dishes from here.
author: Taffany H.

description:
Talk about a big menu. This place has over 120 apps/noodles soups/entrees to offer. Toss in drinks and dessert, they have close to 150.

Bun Bo Hue was good and Banh Canh wasn't bad. Apps are a bit pricey...same price as an entree which is around $7-$8. The sauce for the Goi Cuon was different from the usual peanut sauce. I liked it.

Staff is nice. Place is clean.
author: Julie L.

description: This place is amazing. I've never been to a Vietnamese restaurant with the range of menu options they had, and they're all so on point!! I visited family in Vietnam a year ago and the breakfast dish I had here gave me crazy flashbacks, lmao. Try their steak with eggs and baguette, it's tender and delicious. I gotta come back to try their banh cuon though. I tried my boyfriend's bun bo hue and it was good, too. The broth was on the lighter side for the dish, with good aromatic depth to the taste. We also had banh bot loc and I really loved the sauce for it (/crying face emoji). The texture was nice and chewy and the meat filling was fresh. Don't come here if you're craving regular Viet dishes like pho -- I mean I'm sure that's tasty here too, but they really specialize in dishes that you have to look hard to find otherwise, the stuff your (Viet-Chinese) mom probably fed you while growing up, lmao. The service here is super nice too, thanks for the great meal!!! If I can wake my ass up early enough, I'm making this place my weekend morning routine.
author: Lucy T.

description:
They have a pretty decent bowl of bun no hue here! Cheap, authentic, and super yummy with rockin broth. 
       
    The bun no hue here is BOMB.com; super authentic and the closest to the real thing as you can get in the city. The portions are pretty big and they use the thicker vermicelli rice noodles, so that'll definitely fill you up. They also add a bunch of yummies like: pork blood, pig feet, and pork cake. Also their broth is super good: spicy, flavorful, and satisfying. Perfect for a rainy day or any day! 

Tip: comes with standard jalapeños, bean sprout, basil, and limes! Add them as you like!
author: Janet K.

description: This is my favorite true go to Vietnamese restaurant ever . I like the staff very much as they make you feel like home here. Yummy everything .
author: Ro C.

description:
I reviewed this restaurant on Vietnamese Food Safari.  

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Vietnamese-Food-Safari/419178561516824
author: Duke D.

description:
Bun Bo Hue is just the right amount of spicy and the slightly sour, spicy, and savory flavor is memorable enough to me to get flashbacks of it days later. 
Vietnamese ice coffee is sweet and strong just how I like it. 
I will be back here soon and updates will follow me.
author: Norris T.

description:
I've been eating pho since I was 2 years old. I was sadly disappointed by the lack of flavor in their pho broth... I could have made it better myself! If you HAVE to add lime, Hoisin sauce, and Sriracha to the broth just so you can taste ANYTHING, the cook is not making the broth properly. I also asked for the beef to be placed on the side, so I could add it to the soup myself... it prevents you from having a bowl full of overcooked meat... I got a messy plate of meat chunks. Pho beef should be sliced thinly and evenly. Maybe the cook needs to sharpen his knife. The meat was tough and stringy. The noodles were a little overcooked/mushy, which is more of an SF thing, according to my Vietnamese mother... she likes pho in San Jose much better. She's the expert, so I trust her opinion.

Tuyet Mai? Meh. No worth going back.
author: Suzi G.

description:
In short, I was taken here and fell in love with the pho style here. The pork, chicken or duck noodle soup all I really liked. The young lady that works here is so easy talking to when ordering and treats her business very professional. 

Good hidden place, usually does not get crowded so I always felt comfortable. 

Parking isnt hard to find depending hour you can. Recommend for early lunch. 

Price meets quality
author: Yosof R.

description:
Cute little hole in the wall place. I've been looking for a place with good vietnamese crepes and while this wasn't the best I've had, it was still good!

* Banh Xeo - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ngoc-mai-restaurant-san-francisco?select=SV6whOjq41s-2D9h1B4aJw#SV6whOjq41s-2D9h1B4aJw
(vietnamese crepe with pork, shrimp, & bean sprout. $6)
The crepe was more on the crispy side. It was a little hard to eat since it tended to just snap apart pretty easily and it was really, REALLY overflowing with bean sprouts. Also the contents were not very well distributed - there were 2 shrimp at each of the very ends of the crepe, a couple pieces of pork, and the middle was just that giant pile of bean sprouts. The dipping sauce - AMAZING! We forgot to utilize the lettuce & mint - that probably would've made it better.

* #60 Cam Go Nuong - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ngoc-mai-restaurant-san-francisco?select=SV6whOjq41s-2D9h1B4aJw#Na6k59bxYicfAl55rpeSXw
(five spices BBQ chicken over rice. $6)
This chicken was very crispy, very fried. The meat itself was tender but a little on the dry side - it was actually good that way, made you have to work for it! The dipping sauce - same as above: awesome.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I have found my new favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the Tenderloin. Tied in 1st with Turtle Tower (which I only go to for Pho Ga).

Bun Xia (the flour crepe) was pretty good, I think better than the stuff in San Jo because it's less oily, but more crispy, with extra fresh toppings inside. It's $8, but I have to say I'm just not a fan of this dish in general.

The (#1) Bun Bo Hue DOES live up to the hype. It's a clear soup broth - sweet, a little vinegar-y, and spicy with medium sized white noodles. It came with beansprouts and mint, and it was very fresh. It's a pretty generous portion for only $8!

The (#10) combination dry vermicelli noodles were seriously amazing. I always default to pho because I feel like nothing can beat a nice big bowl of steaming savory noodles, but this one does. It comes with a generous amount of gravy like sauce, and the noodles are perfectly chewy, topped with chicken and seafood. Sounds weird, tastes delicious. It also comes with a side of soup! $9 and worth every penny.

I've had better cafe su da (Viet Iced Coffee), this one was really milky, but you can ask for it with less milk. 

This place is UNUSUALLY friendly and clean. It's always a good sign when the bathroom doesn't reek. Yes, what a paradox for an Asian restaurant, right? Everything was tasty, portions were big, the place was clean, and they take credit for orders $15 and more.
author: Jess C.

description: Small cute family run business in Tendernob. They have lots of options! Especially dishes that are super authentic and region specific in Vietnam. Their food is like comfort food for me. Place is pretty clean. Closes early. I got the Banh Khot, Bun Bo Hue, and Pho. It's all really good!!! Good place to eat, decently priced.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Granted that I almost absolutely despise anything remotely Vietnamese-ish (and I can say that without being racist because I'm Vietnamese), I've got to say Tuyet Mai has the absolute most friendly mom and pop family working in their humble little shop! And sweet service for any kind of Asian place, particularly the tenderloin of all places, this place is a gift from the dirty San Franciscan gods. 

I mostly come here large Togo orders for my work, so even then I don't expect amazing service. But every time I'm in, I'm offered hot tea as I wait and they even offer to help me carry my bags back to my office! Which is absolutely cray since it's a couple blocks down. Super sweet! 

Food wise, their banh beo's and banh uoc's are some awesome home style Vietnamese comfort! All set with tangy fish sauce for trip down nostalgia for folks like myself who aren't to crazy about the cuisine. Since I've never really dined in to comment on their soups and brothy dishes, I can only say that many of their dry plates (fried rices, spring rolls, noodles) were all fairly competent in terms of your standard Vietnamese food fare goes. Does it beat San Jose's Viet food scene? Egh. But it's probably the place to go if you're hankering for some banh Xeo (super good here btw) if you're in the area. 

Friendly folks, decent Viet food that doesn't deter me = Aca-Awesome! (Just watched pitch perfect 2, forgive me)
author: Kero D.

description:
A random hole in the wall type of joint, super easy to miss, but SOLID pho.

Bun Bo Hue is listed as #1 on their menu rather than the traditional beef pho and if pho can ever be "on point"- this would be it.

The broth was neither greasy or overwhelming or full of MSG or too spicy. Normally it would probably be disgusting to find anyone finishing the actual pho broth due to the amount of oil, MSG, or other miscellaneous health reasons, but I downed nearly the whole thing without any shame. I must admit, this is the first time I've ever finish a whole bowl of pho, which speaks volumes.

The only complaint I have would be the portion. A regular consisted of 5 pieces or so of beef, a thin cut of pork feet, one slice (not even cube) of pork blood, and one small handful of noodles. The large didn't seem much larger by comparison. But I guess as the saying goes- quality over quantity any day.
author: Ada C.

description: Solid hole in the wall place for vietnamese food. This is my go to place for bun bo hue, as they do it much better than any of the other vietnamese restaurants in the area. They're also on grubhub, which is awesome for those mornings that you just want a bowl of soup but don't want to do anything active. Good place to explore different vietnamese dishes not called pho.
author: Derrick W.

description: I enjoyed the savory duck noodle broth in the noodle soup that I ordered for lunch in a quiet Saturday afternoon ambiance. Expansive menu of ban mi, noodle soups, dry noodle meals, and rice meals for a good inexpensive meal. Impressed with the freshness of the lime, bean sprouts, and the basil leaves on the side. I highly Recommend this small family-owned restaurant to any fans of Vietnamese cuisine. Go there now.
author: Susan T.

description:
Good service but worst Vietnamese food in SF. Banh Xeo didn't have anything inside except 2 shrimp with tails still on and really fatty chicken. 

Pho ga was terrible. Broth wasn't even close to par. Couldn't eat the chicken as is super fatty. Not one price of edible white meat in the whole bowl. 

They can't control the neighborhood smelling like urine and prostitutes on the corner. They can control the food and should. Likely why there were only 2 other people in the whole restaurant on a Friday night. Too much good food in SF to eat here.  Go elsewhere.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Their Banh xeo is amazing here, it is very crispy and it comes with a lot of lettuce and herbs for you to wrap and dip into the fish sauce. I ordered the bun bo hue and it was relatively good, it is hard to find good BBH in the city and not a lot of Vietnamese restaurants have it on their menu. They also do not skimp out on the meat too! The portions are big for their noodle soups, I had trouble finishing my food. The rice plates are really good as well especially the pork chop ones. I remember coming here when I was really young with my uncle and cousin for the rice plates.
author: Janet Z.

description:
Best hangover cure spot! 

It's okay, I'm not cheating on Turtle Tower. This is completely different kind of hangover cure! I love this place because of all the authentic vietnamese appetizers and noodle soup (other than pho or pho ga) here. 

Let me tell you, coming here on a saturday or sunday morning is like going to AA meeting with a bunch of hungovers. Everyone reek of alcohol from the crazy night before, errrrbody looks like sh*t haha complaining about how much they hate alcohol, and of course everybody is dying for that hot steamy bowl of noodle soup! 

Every time I'm here, we always over order. Our eyes are always bigger than our stomach, trying to order all the amazing appetizers they have here such as Banh Xeo (the crepe with mushroom, beans sprouts and shrimp), fried calamari, and that vietnamese steamed rice cake thingy (sorry i forgot the name). They also have similar dry pho as Ha Na Nimh but it's a little different. 

Must try - BUN BO HUE & BUN RIEU
It's absolutely delicious! It hits the spot if you are looking for some hot steamy soup other than regular beef pho. The soup base is so bomb, not much MSG. Personally I don't really order beef pho anymore so I wouldn't know how their regular pho tastes like. And I only order pho ga from Turtle tower now, so I won't be a judge for that either. 

The area.... hmm it is in the center of Tenderloin but so are most of amazing vietnamese spots. Just be careful and don't forget about the sunday meter parking when you are all hungover and eager to get that bowl of noodle soup! 

Enjoy! xoxo
author: Mindy C.

description: This awesome little restaurant is open again! I think they did some remodeling to the kitchen. Great prices and huge menu. We had the pork and shrimp summer rolls, duck salad, vegetarian crepe, and the dry chicken rice noodle bowl. All superb. The duck salad was the favorite, just so fresh and the duck was tender. Service was fast. The best Vietnamese I've had in California!
author: Ali R.

description: I love this cute lil hole in the wall, every time I come in they are always welcoming. This place is family owned and ran and the food is the closest to my mama's kitchen that I can get in SF. I highly recommend this place if you want flavorful authentic Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Teresa T.

description: Service pretty friendly but food is not at all impressive. Tasteless pho soup and very light meals for the price.
author: Monnikka M.

description:
Came here on Saturday with some friends who've not tried a Vietnamese food before.

Really sad to say that I was really disappointed with my favorite dish Mi quang which was not mi quang at all!! The broth was so watery watery and lacked any flavor. The  banh khot was crunchy and pleased everyone as did the banh bo lot.

Ngoc Mai feels like an intimate little cafe rather than a restaurant but you will get attentive service and a good range of Vietnamese food here for great value but not every dish will be a crowd pleaser.
author: Sahara B.

description: Not sure why this place has such high reviews. We got the banh xeo to start, but it was so flaky it completely fell apart when you tried to eat it. Both of us had the number one bun boh hoe and while the broth was good everything else was not. The mystery meat in there did not taste good.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
My goodness they have a LOT on their menu!
Feel bad rating a place just by going there once, but I gotta say I wasn't super blown away.

Their other noodle bowls and dishes seem to be their main thing rather than pho, etc.

Bun bo hue was pretty good, but I've gotta say that I've never had the real deal so I don't really have anything to compare it to :S

They also have beef stew, bun rieu, etc. 

Banh xeo was good! Crispy with lots of veggies on the side.

Great service, came in, was seated promptly with piping hot tea, clean bathroom.

I'd say pretty it's a solid viet place in the TL when you want something different from pho.
author: Alexis P.

description: One of my Vietnamese favorite restaurant. Family owned, really nice people. Good cook. Good food. My favorite has to be the crepe and sour soup with cat fish.
author: Queenie L.

description:
This place is solid! It's now one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the Tenderloin. I was surprised to see that they have a list of appetizers and small dishes from Hue (banh beo, banh bot loc and more) since you usually don't find these dishes outside of San Jose.

Their menu has most of the regional dishes from Vietnam whether bun bo hue, bun rieu, mi quang, pho, hu tieu, bo kho... you can find everything here whether it's egg noodles, pho noodles, vermicelli, beef stews with baguette, iced coffee, che. Great menu and friendly service!

I really loved the bun bo hue. It was not too spicy and you can smell/taste the lemongrass adding to the sour and mildly sweet broth. There are blood cubes in the soup, which is normal, and you can ask to leave it out. They're there by default.

I will be coming back :)
author: Camille L.

description:
Best Vietnamese in the City, hands down.

The chicken pho and chicken salad appetizer are amazing and the banh xeo (crepe appetizer) and bun bo xao sa (lemongrass beef with warm noodle) are to die for. Everything is very fresh and flavorful and not oily or greasy as you might find at other places.

Also a large selection of more obscure local dishes from the city of Hoa like duck soup with pig's blood or sweet and sour catfish head.

Mai, who usually works front of house, is so sweet and pleasant and makes great Vietnamese iced coffee. Mom and pop are in the kitchen and don't skimp on the good stuff!!

They close early (6-6:30ish), so go for lunch or grab take-out for dinner.
author: Teo W.

description:
Just had dinner here tonight and for some odd reason felt like eating a hot bowl of comforting soup.  There is NOTHING else that compares to a good bowl of Bun Bo Hue, Hu Tieu, Bun Rieu or Pho when the weather is cold.  I found that it was the only place open and within quick walking distance from Lower Nob Hill and thought I'd give it a go.  

It was funny that the server who was on break, was actually eating a bowl of Bun Bo Hue.  I opted for that after seeing the yelp pics of it.  Pretty close to what you might find on the streets of Vietnam I'll be honest and the service was just as quick too.  Probably took less than 8 minutes from the order in the kitchen.  I was also sitting right next to this dutch door they use as a order pickup window.  

The Bun Bo Hue, spicy red chili flake goodness.  I was coughing from the spicy broth after sipping it for taste.  The quality of the dark beef cuts are the best you'll find around.  Fresh and soft to the bite.  One of the best components of the soup.  Don't forget to throw the mint leaves and bean sprouts in your soup!  Cools it down and adds some light texture of flavor to it.  I got one blood block and one fatty pig knuckle which is a MUST in Bun Bo Hue.  Didn't add any sauces except for squeezes of lemon throughout eating it.  

It is a tiny joint but was not overcrowded when I came in.  Everyone complimented the food on their way out while I was eating.  The family or people who run the places are very nice and gave some steamed rice to a homeless guy who stumbled in drunk when I was there.  I'll be back to try Bun Rieu next time, I rarely get to eat decent Vietnamese food when I'm in this part of SF.  But I believe some of the best joints seems to be in the TL.
author: Kenny P.

description: I've been coming here since I was a kid. Love this place. Have to try it to believe it.
author: Nart T.

description: I've been on the hunt for good Vietnamese food ever since I moved to SF. On a cold day, I was craving soups and this came up on my Yelp search. It's definitely a hole in the wall and very small with only a couple tables tightly next to each other. However, it seemed clean.. Service was very good also. They were very attentive. I got the bun bo hue (spicy beef noodle soup) and the bf got pho. I thought both dishes were a bit on sweeter side. I had to put a lot of lemon and sirarcha/peppers to tone it down a bit. I would say the soups were okay. In comparison to SJ, I would take Bun Bo Hue An Nam or Pho Y over this place any day. But for SF, it's not bad. I definitely liked the bun bo hue more than the pho, but despite what I say about it being sweet, I'll still probably be back to try their other dishes and rate on those since I'm usually in that area and I'm really curious as to how everything else tastes.
author: Jenn N.

description: This is family style hospitality. We love this place. It has great vegetarian options too. Delicious, fresh, authentic Vietnamese food at a great price!
author: Megan N.

description:
the BBH everyone is talking about here, I don't know what's so special about it. 
I actually didn't like it at all. the taste was very boring. 
but I actually fell in love with their spring rolls. the sauce is sooo good!
it's the best spring rolls I've ever had. 
and the waitress is so nice. when I ordered spring rolls to go she gave me a tea whilst I was waiting for my takeout and opened the door for me when I left. 
so overall experience of this place is pretty good. I'll be coming back for their spring rolls and maybe I'll try their pho. not BBH.
author: Carli C.

description: Great little restaurant. Amazing food and good service in a no-frills little restaurant. Banh xeo was fantastic!  Will be back again.  One of the better restaurants in little Saigon for sure.
author: Julien B.

description: I ordered banh bot loc, banh xeo and banh beo for my dinner with my friend. The dishes were decent but the lady owner was nice to me so I give four stars.
author: Linh C.

description:
This is our second time at this joint and the service is super but the food is where the 3 stars comes in. Unless you just want the service and have no clue what V food is like you may disagree with me. 

I ordered Pho and they didn't have the greens that goes with Pho. Yep that's right no cilantro no mint and that's the two important thing in Pho :). Not really but aside from that the pho was cloudy and tastes like it was old soup from yesterday. Mind you that this is the second time that I have tried this place so I'm not giving it 3 stars without giving them a chance. 

My wife had BBH which was ok per her comments. 

Would we come back here again, yes until there is some better choice for V food in SF. Until then we will keep searching. 

Have fun yelping.
author: Neo N.

description:
I was craving Bun Bo Hue and a TL adventure on a rainy weekend in San Francisco, and Tuyet Mai satisfied both of those criteria. The restaurant was empty on a Saturday night around 6PM and can seat about 10 tables. The food here is fairly disturbing, but the couple who own it are so nice and patient. So first off, kudos to them!

The BBH is very affordable (~$8/small). My friend was explaining how it takes a day to brew the broth, and my other friend tasted his bowl and promptly said "This doesn't taste like it took a day." The broth is pretty flavorless if you really concentrate on it; it tastes like they dumped a lot of spices/oil on top right before they serve it to you. The noodles are strangely overcooked, as if they've been frozen too long and then boiled as long as possible.

We also shared an order of summer rolls (~$7.50/three). I know these rolls are always a rip off at Vietnamese restaurants, but this was actually ridiculous. I felt like I was eating mouthfuls of iceberg lettuce and bean sprouts... and that's it. There was also a very strange flavor to the rolls and my friend said we would all know the cause of our death if we keeled over the next day. So there's that.

There are much better Vietnamese joints in the TL and SF in general. There were also fruit flies circling our table.
author: Jessica F.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Bun Bo Hue = pretty good! Was promised good Vietnamese food here ever since moving from Vietnam central of SJ... FINALLY something to fill my pho and bunbohue cravings
2.) Spring Roll

*I shall come back next I need my Viet food fixin'


SERVICE:
O man the family working here are so nice ;)


ATMOSPHERE:
Very small simple pho place in the Tenderloin

9.913
author: Angela L.

description: We here for lunch with friends on Sunday and everything was good.  We all had bun bo hue and we all think it was.  Banh khoc and banh bot loc both were good.  The Vietnamese coffee was not that good since I like my to be sweet, but my husband says it was good.  The services was friendly and nice.
author: Food-Travel-Adventure A.

description:
Wow, first time here, came with a bunch of friends for lunch today, very good.....

We had spring rolls, the best of all places I have tried, the lettuce that comes with it is so fresh.....

I ordered the bbq pork and rice.....it was good, I love their rice....texture with fish sauce poured all over just makes it perfect.....

My friends had the number one and two, broth was delicious.....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
I really really REALLY wanted to like the pho here, since I still have yet to find a good pho restaurant in the city (besides Turtle Tower). The broth was good, but not amazing, and the quality of meat in the pho dac biet was a bit lacking. Overall great portions for the price though.

I did really like their hu tieu noodles and the spring rolls, and would come back for that.
author: Vivian H.

description:
It was a rainy day in the Tenderloin last week.
I poked my head inside Ngoc Mai and decided to stay.
I grabbed the window seat.
My view? a window aquarium and the Tenderloin crazies.
I also sat right next to the kitchen and the view was entertaining!

My order? A Large #1 Bun Bo Hue (or BBH)
The broth was sweet and mild. I had to add chili peppers to make it more spicy.
The noodles were cooked nicely and was ample.
The meats include sliced pork and beef, pork sausage, pig's feet, and cubes of congealed pig's blood. Good noshing here...
The side-veggies included bean spouts, stalks of mint leaves, and lemon wedges.

The owners are really nice.
I just love this soup on a rainy day.

The only craziness I managed to view was a Tenderloin "local" wearing a Glad trash-bag as a poncho.  He kept trying to light his cigarette in front of the restaurant. Flick, flick flick with his lighter. This must have went on for a couple of minutes. He peered in the window, squinted and walked away. 

okay...so, I would eat here again!
author: Derek N.

description: I had stir fried noodles with shrimp today. I like the sweet sauce in the noodles. Haha, I have become a Vietnamese food lover recently
author: Jia W.

description: Great spring rolls. The service was very attentive. The new name is HUONG YI HUE. We are from Florida. I would die for a place like this near us. San Francisco is soooo luck to have this kind of great original Vietnames food.
author: Chester S.

description:
Wow just a block away from me, yay.  I really like this place mostly for its hole in the wall vibe haha. It's smallish but not too tiny. They take credit cards! Service was really good, server was super nice. You can see grandma cooking in the kitchen LOL. 

They have a pretty extensive menu and most in Vietnamese and of course the English translation doesn't really describe well. So I took advice of Yelpers. I can't remember the names but it's #1 and #3 on first page.. spicy beef (Bun Bo Hue?) and crab tofu pho. I really liked the crab, and spicy beef was good. We also ordered the Banh Xeo (crepe) which was tasty and fun to eat. We can't wait to go back and try their other items.
author: Vol T.

description:
Sad to hear this place is closed. Everything I tried there was good. 
The banh khot, banh xeo were good.  It was crispy which I like.
The bbh was also pretty good.  Probably one of the better ones I've had.
author: Heejin L.

description:
We came here for a pre-movie lunch last Sunday afternoon. Based on previous reviews and recommendations, we were looking forward to it!

We grabbed a table for four and ordered as soon as we were all together. Our order consisted of two orders of spring rolls (one tofu, one meat), a bowl of soup, the duck salad, and barbecue pork on rice. 

The food was excellent and delicious, but two things prevent me from giving this place four stars.

First, I requested the vegetarian egg rolls. I was told they might not have any and she'd go check. Came back, nope, no egg rolls. I had been checking the menu quick to figure out another option in case they didn't have them, so I said I'd have the vegetarian pot stickers. Guess what? Not available either! What. This kinda tells me that they don't make these fresh at all, they're pre-prepped or frozen. Ugh. Ok, so I ordered the fresh tofu spring rolls. They had that, so great.

Second, and this is where I got really frustrated, was the food came out very staggered. The meat spring rolls came out first, followed by the duck salad, both of which were for one of our party. Next came the soup for someone else. After about 5 minutes, the pork/rice dish came out. Which left mine last... the non-cooked tofu spring rolls. Those took at least 10 minutes, if not 15, before they arrived, after everyone else was at least half-way through their meal (I didn't want anyone waiting on it). Other later arrivals' food came out before mine, while I sat there wondering if they'd just outright forgotten it. It eventually did, but wow, I shouldn't have had to wait that long for it.

The food we ordered is amazing, easily worth 4 stars... but the service really left a lot to be desire.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Took advantage of Sunday Streets to explore this part of town and found a space nearby.  Not knowing what to expect, I checked on Yelp and saw best Bun Bo Hue - that was enough to get me inside.

It's small but bright and clean. The young girl taking order was nice.  What we had:

iced coffee w/ condensed milk - $3 - made and served in milkshake glass.  tasty

large bun bo hue - $9 including tax - I knew it wasn't authentic based on the sides they provide (no banana flower or cabbage) and the ingredients (slices of pork?).  It was ok - I asked for extra spicy but it wasn't.  Luckily, they have some pepper flakes at the table I can spice things up.  The blood cake was over cooked.  

pork and shrimp spring rolls - $8 including tax - came with a small bowl of diluted hoisin sauce with crushed peanuts. tightly wrapped, it's ok.
author: Gloria H.

description: I was in SFO for business and I went here with a friend. The food was great. Everything we ordered was delicious
author: Bobby B.

description: Amazing Vietnamese food! Loved the bun bo hue and the cold pork patties. Total hole in the wall and semi sketchy surroundings but totally worth it place if you like Vietnamese food
author: Sara C.

description: love this little restaurant. the place is small but very clean. staffs are friendly. they have the best bun bo hue in the city and their bun xeo and bun khot are good too. i live far but i still come here when i can. always want to try new dishes but still end up ordering their bun bo hue plus bun xeo or bun khot. oh, i suggest everyone to take your time to enjoy their tea. it has a light floral scent to it, unlike other places where they serve you regular red tea. the male waiter, he's hardly there anymore, told me their family friend blend the tea for them. he was nice enough to give me a small cup of the tea leaves and in it i see different kinds of tea leaves and dried rose buds. i asked a few times if they sell the tea and they said no.   ='( ....sniff sniff
author: Tofu O.

description:
It's a dirty, family run, hole in the wall joint.

BUN BO HUE.

that's all.

If you can't hang with the dirt, then GTFO.
author: Susy C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by Tuyet, a small Vietnamese restaurant tucked away in the Tenderloin. We walked in ten minutes before closing on a weeknight and thought they would turn us away... but instead the server happily welcomed us in and give us great service. The menu was extensive (definitely need to try the porridge next time...) and everything sounded delicious. I ended up ordering the Bun Bo Hue and I loved how they were able to kindly accommodate my weird requests (not too spicy, wider noodles, etc). My friend and I didn't end up leaving until an hour after they closed. And we only left because we were in food coma, not because we felt rushed (they didn't clear our bowls passive aggressively like most restaurants would).

The food hit the spot but it was the great service and ridiculously clean environment that made me want to jump on Yelp!
author: Kat K.

description:
so came because this was the only pho joint that took card and was pretty highly rated. 

First yellow flag, it's lunchtime 12o'clock and it's deserted. 
but whatever, there are a lot of pho places and it's a warm day. 

Second, $15 minimum for card. 

Third, i ordered the chicken pho, which they later charged me $8....just rounded up i suppose.
lacked chicken, and tasted like soap....there were bubbles near the edge of the bowl, due to not cleaning the bowl thoroughly? i'm not sure. but it was really disappointing. 

Fourth, any authentic pho place will have cilantro and onions. I always ask for a side of cilantro and extra onions. What I received were chopped up green onions...and other mint leaves?..

Overall. NO. 

also, to satisfy the minimum i ordered the combination porridge
author: Christina O.

description:
This place is a little gem tucked away in the Tenderloin. A nice Vietnamese restaurant with a great variety of foods from rice plates to soups, not just pho. 

I had the large bun bo hue and for $8 dollars I was satisfied. The broth was Delicious and not overly spicy. Tasted authentic and not like many places where they just or some spicy sauce over ho broth. 

the service was great and the waitress was extremely friendly. I would definitely recommend this place t my friends.
author: Alvin L.

description: Delicious home style cooked Vietnamese food with friendly service!  I had the egg rolls, ban xeo (viet crepe), bun bo hue, and mi quang.  My favorites were the egg rolls and mi quang, but it was all very tasty.  Can't wait to return to try other items.
author: short t.

description: I discovered this place by chance.  It is a small hole in a wall but very clean and the food is excellent!  We ordered the Bun Bo Hue, scallop fried rice, and a combo portridge and everything was EXCELLENT.  Will definitely come back and try other things on the menu.
author: Kacee B.

description:
I still stand by my complaint that I haven't found a decent Vietnamese soup restaurant in San Francisco (I used to like Pho Garden on Clement but haven't been in last few years because they spend too much effort on their silly Pho Challenge rather than maintaining the quality food they used to serve)

Unfortunately the Bun Rieu at Ngoc Mai isn't very good.  Perhaps I have been too spoiled by Vietnamese friends who are amazing cooks but after reading all the rave reviews for the Bun Rieu, I was willing to hold my breath through the urine soaked streets of the Loin to slurp on some good Vietnamese soup.  Not worth it.  The soup was boring, certainly not flavorful, spicy, or anything you would attribute to amazing Vietnamese flavors.  Also, no crab insight!  WTH - don't describe it as crab soup and then leave out the crab!  $9 later and I felt ripped off.
author: Lev E.

description:
The quest of the mi quang that will finally satisfy my craving goes on. Ngoc Mai just wasn't good enough.

Still the banh xeo, and banh beo were really tasty as were my friend's bun bo hue. Get those things and not the mi quang.
author: Misha T.

description:
This place offers mighty tasty Bun Bo Hue. Seriously, when I walked in, I thought I had entered a home. The restaurant was lined with cute white tiles throughout the whole room. There was also an extremely large fly cruising around the place. 

Other than that, the bun bo hue was delicious. It had everything a bowl of bun bo hue should have! Pig feet, pig's blood, beef, lemon grass, chewy noodles. Yummm! The price was decent for SF. A bowl is $7.95 and you can definitely get full off of it!
author: Joyce M.

description: This place looks like mini house. I got the BBH and it was actually pretty good! Prob one of the best places I've had in SF! (Sj is still #1). My friend got pho and he liked it too although he said the meat wasn't too good. I tried it and it was pretty tough, not sure if it was just the cut or what. Got the viet coffee too, super bitter and strong. It took a while to get the food, unlike other pho restaurants where your food comes out instantly so you know they're cooking with some TLC!
