We didn't order anything else but they had a huge selection of viet foods that I don't normally see at other restaurants. I would def come back and try other dishes like banh xeo
author: naviee P.

description: The first time I tried this restaurant, I tried a regular bowl of Pho and it was delicious.  It was perfect for the cold, brisk day.  I noticed on the reviews that the Bun Bo Hue was a popular item so I came back another time to try that. It is now my favorite on the menu!  I really like is the friendly customer service.  Even when you order to-go, they will give you a cup of hot tea.  If you order a soda to go, they will also give you a cup of ice with a lid on it and straw.  Now that I have lived in the TL for over two years, this is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant
author: Neville B.

description: My first review.. Shame it has to start as a not so good one. I'll start by saying this is a lovely nice clean place with friendly staff. Vietnamese is one of my favourite cuisines, and I say you can always judge a Vietnamese by it's regular pho. So I ordered Pho Tai and a side of pot stickers... First of all the pot stickers were just deep fried and had lost all the flavour and when my pho arrived there was some kind of white meat in it, I kindly advised that this was not beef and was told it is 'rare beef' like I was some kind of idiot who didn't know what rare beef looked like.. The broth was bland, had been heavily seasoned with God knows what and I had to add a lot of sriracha to make it taste ok. I picked out all the 'rare beef! And ate the noodles & broth! Very disappointed and I hope that this was a one off because it looked like a nice little spot!
author: Marc G.

description:
this place is awesome! i love the TL for good vietnamese food! 

I love their mini crepes with the shrimp (#22)!  The crepes freshly made so when it comes to the table its hot and crispy!! i love it! 

and of course a must get is their BBH (bun bo hue) - so tasty and full of flavor! i love the pork cake that they have in the soup!! 

so happy that there's good bbh without having to go all the way to SJ!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Awesome, awesome bun bo hue in the city!

The waitress was super attentive and provided excellent service. The broth was the perfect level of spiciness and had a depth of flavor. The noodles weren't too soft and had a great consistency. It would've been nicer if the bowl were a tad bigger, but I was still completely full (with a small bun bo hue) by the meal's end. The large is only a dollar or so more so probably worth it if you're hungrier.

I only had the bun bo hue that everyone mentions, but it was enough to prompt a return. It really is as good as my Vietnamese boyfriend's mother's, and she makes it pretty freaking amazingly.
author: Shira C.

description: One of the very few great Vietnamese restaurants that the city has to offer.  Great mien trung cuisine.  Bun bo hue is great here and so are the banh khot!  This place along with Ha Nam Ninh are the places I'll come back to whenever I miss authentic Vietnamese food.  Service is great here too, the main waitress is very soft spoken and sweet :)
author: Christina L.

description:
I love this place. I think the parents cook and the daughter is the waitress and cashier.
Its the next best thing to homemade mama's cooking!
I usually order Bun Bo Hue, Cha Hue and Cha Tom.
I love to add more shrimp paste and roasted chili flakes for more authentic flavor as well.

Thats spicy beef vermicelli noodle soup with pigs feet, pork pattiies and shrimp patties.
Technically they aren't patties but I guess thats the best thing to call them.

the pork one I like to call Vietnamese bologna but cut in chunks and wedges instead of slices. same with the shrimp. Yumm!

The place is small and gets a good amount of loyal customers so avoid lunch rush hour if you can. 

It's a mom & pop shop. Nohting fancy. Just good food and friendly people.
author: My D.

description: Bun Bo Hue is very good. In fact, they have a series of Hue's food (Hue is an ancient city in the middle of Vietnam). This place was previously called "Ngoc Mai", which is my go-to place for BBH.
author: Cuong P.

description:
If you like Bún Thit Nuong, this place is for you. The noodles are super light and fluffy, the veggies are freshly chopped before they fall into your bowl and the pork is perfectly seasoned.  There are plenty of other toppings for you to choose from. All sounded amazing. 

FYI - The pho here seems northern style, so it wasn't my jam. Or my dining buddy's. Also, they now take cards. Win!
author: Karena Q.

description: The spartan interior and "transitional neighborhood" work together to conceal a glimmering Vietnamese culinary jewel in the upper corner of the Tenderloin's "Little Saigon" microhood. The kitchen is spotless and efficient, and the food coming out of it is fantastically flavorful and hearty. I wholeheartedly recommended you order some lunch takeout from them.
author: West R.

description: I've never liked pho until I had it at Tuyet Mai.  It's usually so bland at other places, but everything was seasoned just right here.  I'll be back soon, thanks!
author: Jason D.

description:
DISCLAIMER: I am VIetnamese.

The Good:
  :: it's a hole in the wall in san francisco in the sketchy tenderloin district. this makes it a GOLD thing, people. i looove me some hole in the wall businesses!!
  :: pho broth was amazing. so flavorful...didn't need to add any condiments to it. 
  :: pho noodles were perfectly tender
  :: the beef in the pho tai was very tasty and plentiful
  :: fresh huge fixins. the mint leaves were HUGE. sprouts were fresh and white and crisp. they gave us a HUGE plate of sliced peppers to put into the broth if we were bold. sorry. we were not bold.
  :: clean sitting area
  :: sweet woman working there...not sure if she is one of the owners or not, but i'm pretty sure she is. she made us feel totally welcome. she called me "con" like my mom and dad call me. Awwwww!!!

The Bad:
  :: the bo vien wasn't the best. plentiful but not tasty. 
  :: very small interior. this is not a place for a big group of people. grab a table by the window so that you can do some memorable people watching!

The Ugly:
  :: none

Would I go back? In a heartbeat. Can't wait to go back next time I am in SF! Wish we had more hole in the wall places like this here in Austin. 

This place is IN.
author: Carolyn V.

description:
Wow might be my new favorite vietnamese spot in the city.

This isn't a fancy spot, nor is it in a nice neighborhood...

However,  they give big portions for cheap and the flavors are all there.  The people working there are suuuuper nice and the inside decor has a very welcoming and homey feel to it.  I felt like i was eating at a friends house.
Reminds me of how a lot of the best spots in Hawaii are.


Get:
Clay Pot Catfish - If you like catfish this stuff was awesome.  It does not come in a clay pot, but they give you like 3 or 4 big pieces and it is cooked in a sauce that is similar to San Tung Wings.

Vermicelli Noodles - Big Bowl and just delicious.  Great if you don't feel like getting Pho.

Duck Curry Pho - Didn't get to try this, but my buddy polished the huge bowl clean in record time... 

Okay: 
Banh Xeo - Tasted Delicious, but i think it is kinda hard to eat.  This is a personal preference, but i still think I would like the spring rolls better.
author: Steven F.

description:
BUN BO HUEEEEEEEEE!

So ive been here once before long ago with a friend, and i ate BBH too...but it was so long ago i forgot!

Then yesterday, sunday, my bf and I had to head downtown to exchange stuff, so he said lets eat in the tenderloin! I was like ok yippee! vietnamese food! yelped places real quick and saw this place. remembering about BBH, and that i havent had it in a year or so...(when i was in santa cruz, and passed by san jose, there is yummy BBH there)

so we drove and parking wasn't tooo difficult but we did have to circle a bit. Now...you would think....tenderloin, creepy, hole in the walls...would be cheap good food.....but nope! guess my memory took out the prices but man everything was $7 and up! Whoa.

Oh well, since we were already there and starving, why not try it.
bun bo hue small- $8, ah! refreshing and slightly spicy. not the "authentic" kind in sanjo, but still delicious!
banh khot- mini crepe with shrimp. i thought it was a different kind...you know the white one made of rice flour?...wtih egg yolk..and yea. but still very yummy and crispy but $8 for like...8 pieces!??! totally not worth it.
bun thit nuong- good portion, bf liked it.
iced coffee- holy moly it was bitter, but that's why we like it. haha

$30 for everything, not the cheapest but it was good. their nouc mum was good, on the sweeter side, but add some hot sauce and its great!
author: Christine M.

description:
Back in business! But under a new name, Tuyet Mai Restaurant.

Best Bun Bo Hue in town! Also if you're looking for the hard to find Bun Mam, they got it here!

Small restaurant but gives a feeling of home cooked meals.

Oh they serve Banh Xeo too!
author: Kevin V.

description:
Im vegetarian, so the ingredients used in my soup and tofu shredded rolls were pretty fresh.  I thought I was going to have an enjoyable, filling meal.  
The place had a dirty fish tank, with sick fish swimming in it, and boy did that ruin my meal.  I could no longer enjoy the freshness of my vegetarian food.  I tried to look away but I would forget and kept on getting grossed out.  
Please remove that fish tank.  The last thing I want is for something to ruin a meal I had been craving for weeks.
author: Eleazar D.

description:
Small local Vietnamese restaurant in the Tenderloin. The staff is very friendly and accommodating. 

Food is fresh and delicious, and everything I've tried thus far has been great.
author: Naomi C.

description: I give this place a solid 4 for its Bun Bo Hue. The broth is above average. They should add red cabbage or even better banana trunk. The noodles can be longer.
author: Scott L.

description: Always one of my favorites! Just to clarify for those who are not familiar with Vietnamese food; Hue is central Vietnam, their style will most likely be a bit more spicy than other regions.  As some items on the menu are based from Hue, some are not, so expect differences.  Though they may be subtle, if you're used to a Southern style Vietnamese food and come here, you may not have it made the same way.  They are still very good and the family is the same.  Not sure why the name change, but it's still the neighborhood joint for me.
author: Julie L.

description: I am just happy this place reopened. I've been coming here for well over 10 years and let me tell  you, they have GREAT customer service for a start, and their food - WOW!!!! I love their BUN BO HUE but who doesn't. I've tried mostly everything on their menu and they never once failed me. I'd recommend this place over and over and over again. This restaurant is even BETTER than many Vietnamese food establishments in San Jose, CA. Until the day I die, I hope this restaurant will be around for as long as I am or even after my time. Yes, I LOVE the food. Yes, I love their service. C'mon, who wouldn't love a place if they always remember YOU and what you want. Just Love Love Love!!!
author: Rose L.

description: I'm a big fan of BBQ pork bunh and this was a disappointment. First, there was no fried spring roll. Second, the BBQ pork was in large pieces and stringy. Third there were very few veggies (carrots etc). There're lots of good Vietnamese restaurants nearby and this one was full so maybe the other dishes are better. Still, I'm not going back.
author: Mike V.

description:
I was hoping to find the best Bun Bo Hue in the city here.  I was disappointed.  5 stars for having a very wide selection of Vietnamese cuisine, specifically Hue (central) cuisine.  I have very high expectation for Vietnamese food, as I am Vietnamese. Hence, 3 stars for the Bun Bo Hue and Banh Canh Gio Heo.  The best Bun Bo Hue is still at Ca Mau in San Jose.  I think I am done searching...

Service was great. The waitress was really sweet.  I'd come back to try some of the Hue dishes, Bun Hue, and Banh Xeo.  Otherwise, no more BBH!
author: MT D.

description: awesome place the banh xeo for about $8 was scrumptious and one of the  best meals I've had in a long time. The Bun Rieu was also good no real crab but crab flavoring with shrimp. This place is very good for the price and a visit to the tenderloin is a must.
author: N A.

description:
Just went back recently with my husband.  We loved our lunch!  
The Bahn Xeo was crispy and light.  My husband says it's the best he's had yet.  I ordered the curry duck noodle soup, which I took half of home.  The flavor was rich, the duck was tender and the noodles were perfectly cooked.  The hot pepper selection is fantastic, and I am a huge fan of those peppers that look like crushed red peppers, but when dropped in the soup simply melt away. 

Check out my pics. http://gonegluten-free.com/2011/10/06/ngoc-mai-and-the-deliciously-gluten-free-vietnamese-crepe/

This place is great, there are tons of gluten free options (which is why Vietnamese is always a GF staple of mine), lots of bold flavors and a check that makes you wonder how this place can afford to stay in business.
CASH ONLY BUSINESS!
author: Heather S.

description:
BUN UOT! It's pretty good. I like that it was freshly made! The "crepe" style noodles came out steamy hot! Most places would give you the food room temperature. The meat on the other hand was OKAY. I wasn't too wowed but overall Ngoc Mai is pretty good. 

They're more known for their bun bo hue, but I haven't had that in a while so if you ask me for a review of it, it'll kind of be made up...
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
I came here after work on a Friday evening,. THEY WERE CLOSED!! FYI - They close at 6pm!

I finally woke up early enough this Saturday morning to pay this place a visit.  Plenty of metered parking infront of the restaurant and the food comes fast.  The BBH #1 is really good here,. the broth was sweet and spicy, I only felt the spicyness go down my throat and it didn't over power my taste buds.  The noodle/meat portion is a perfect amount for me,. a matter of fact,.  I barely finished my bowl and had to throw meat chunks into my friends bowl. 

I would've gave this place 4 stars,. but there were little critters crawling around my eating area and the cups smelled funny!! eeeeeekkkk

According to my friend "You're in a hole in a wall,.. its expected,. here,. wipe your stuff with the hot tea and napkins"

eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeek! 

I will still come back to eat! 

P.S. I overheard the waitress stating the restaurant will be closed until March because they are going on VACATION! Make sure you call in before you head out to the tenderloin!
author: Chanel L.

description:
One of my favorite vietnamese restaurants in sf. Bun bo hue is spicy and tasty. The banh khot is crispy and served with a good selection of veggies/herb. Banh bot loc is nicely steamed served with balanced fish sauce. Banh beo is the thick kind with lots of toppings (fried shallots, mung beans, etc).

Ca kho to is fried first before it's braised in the caramel sauce. I prefer it not fried (i wonder if we can request). Canh chua ca is very savory with almost no sour taste not the usual clear broth/really tangy/sweet kind, but still delicious.

I didn't enjoy the following dishes as much: banh canh cua, bun mam, banh xeo.
author: Sarah L.

description:
well, like my previous reviews, I do eat bun bo hue everywhere I go....I seek out for it
their bun bo hue was ok, not too tasty
Banh canh tom cua - 1 star - broth was not tasty, shrimp was just plain shrimp, not ground and no pepper, and there is no Crab - just loose egg like egg drop soup....
banh beo - way too thick, no grind shimp and too much onion and mung bean.....
coconut water - NOT fresh, she even brought out a can for me.....
service is great for a Vietnamese restaurant......
author: June L.

description:
We came here specifically for the famed bun bo hue--a spicy beef noodle soup from Hue in Central Vietnam.  I'm not Vietnamese--though I have been to Vietnam--and my review is not based on how authentic or real the bun bo hue is, but just how tasty I thought it was.  In all, the bun bo hue was not bad--very, very spicy with good flavor.  The soup was a little thin and could have used some more herbs to round it out, and the noodles were a little flimsy and overcooked (a big pet peeve of mine).  I enjoyed my meal, but I also wouldn't trip over myself to come back.

One thing I can say is that the service is absolutely wonderful.  The women who run this place are the sweetest restaurant owners I've ever met--always smiling, always gracious, never rude or condescending.  I almost gave them four stars just for that.
author: Matt Y.

description: I was pretty disappointed in this place. I cam here with my friend and the Bun Bo Hue was not that great. Other than lacking flavor, it was lukewarm. I like my soups piping hot! Other than that, they ended up charing us the same price for every dish we ordered $9, when each thing we ordered was different prices... I brought it up and they said it was tax. How does $6 + tax = $9 and $8 + tax = $9. It doesnt.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Came here with my mom, GF and sister on a Sunday afternoon - small place with one waitress but seated easily. 

We shared the Banh Xeo - a crispy Vietnamese crepe-ish type dish served with cooked bean sprouts, pork and shrimp, then wrapped in lettuce and dipped in fish sauce. It was pretty good! The crisp was definitely there. Could have used more pork and shrimp but all in all, good app for 4 people.

GF and I went with Bun Bo Hue and the broth was great! Good spice with a bit of a sour twist and it was piping hot! Good meat to noodle proportion and definitely felt the side basil, bean sprouts, and lime were fresh and not just been sitting in a refrigerator for days.  

Mom had the Bun Rieu - she seemed to enjoy it. I tasted the broth and it had good flavor has well. The only dish I would have passed on was my sister's Chicken Pho. Broth tasted bland and nothing really stood out. Iced coffee was also ok - great taste initially but really milky towards the end.

Street parking only (now we have to pay on Sundays - boooo!) but they now accept CC for orders over $15! A bit out of the way but we will be back to try other dishes!
author: Rich H.

description: I ordered the bun bo hue since it seems like one of the most popular dish here. It tasted really delicious and the noodles were great! However, I feel like the price is high and there was a mosquito flying around, hence the lower stars. My dad complained that his chicken pho soup isn't that flavorful. It seems like a pretty authentic restaurant.
author: Jennifer T.

description: This is by far my favorite Vietnamese restaurant. My favorite is the BBH, pho ga, and especially the bun xiao!!! Recommend the lemon soda less sweet and the Vietnamese coffee!!
author: Daniel K.

description:
Ngoc Mai Restaurant is the epitome of the classic little Asian dive diner and greasy spoon. And you know what you usually get in these types of places? 

Real, authentic food that is delicious, from humble people at decent prices, that's what! 

If you want pomp and circumstance, chi-chi decor and crowds, fancy fruit cocktails, drunk hotties in cocktail dresses or hipsters trying to make the scene, do not come here!  

In fact, most of that superficial stuff is found after dark, and this restaurant, being truly family run, is only open from 10am to 6pm, and only 10am to 3pm on Sundays! 

The other thing you will find here? Working class Vietnamese and some Chinese. I was the only Low Fan (outsider) in this place for lunch (well it is tiny, with only about 7 tables, but still!) and probably the only one all this week.  

The outside is tattered and torn, and could pass for a contractor's storage locker. Inside, it looks like it used to be a bathroom or kitchen, as there is old funky tile on the walls. And the tiny kitchen where they make all this good food, is only slightly bigger than a walk-in closet, with one refrigerator and a small stove. 

They serve "Dac Biet Thuc An Hue" which is specials from Hue in central Vietnam. That means their number 1 listed dish is Bun Bo Hue, the famous hearty, spicy soup from Hue. But they have a very large menu for a very small place, and offer Pho, Bun, Com Dia, Com Chien, and even Canh Chua soup. 

They also offer a couple of things that are slightly harder to find. 
A. Banh Xeo, the half moon crepe I like.
B. Banh U'ot..which is thick rice noodle wrap stuffed with meats, from the south of Vienam.  
C. Dry style Hu Tieu, or Hu Tieu Kho Ngoc Mai, or their special version .

I tried C, the dry Hu Tieu, which Da Lat Restaurant near San Jose State  is famous for serving. 

Hu Tieu is also a noodle dish, and the regular kind is sort of like a Pho soup with broth, and typically with seafood and pork. The dry type is served with none or very little standing broth initially, and is served with a side bowl of  usually chicken broth with green onions. Inside the main bowl, Ngoc Mai served it with shrimp, pork slices, cross-hatched squid bodies, chicken, chopped greens, and a handful of peanuts, all sitting atop the rice noodles, in a puddle of savory, hearty broth.

You can eat it like it was served, sort of halfway between a wet bowl of Pho (but with different ingredients) and a dry plate of Bun (vermicelli noodles). But I pour the chicken broth in and eat. Yum! You do get a lemon wedge and some sliced jalapenos to add to it, and you could add Hoisin and Sriracha, but they are not necessary and would ruin the flavor.

Ngoc Mai also serves you hot tea when you sit down, and the 3 people working are all very nice, but not talkative. They acknowledge you and say thank you. 

Hu Tieu Kho Ngoc Mai and tea was a little more than $7 after tax.  This is a great little Dive DIner with authentic Vietnamese food.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Really great service here. People are the nicest ever. Fast too. LOVE the tea. You can't buy this tea - they mix it there and it's free with your meal.
author: Oki K.

description:
3 1/2 stars

Home cooking in the tenderloin of SF, run by a nice Vietnamese family. I went for the Bun bo hue which was flavorful and slightly spicy and the Bun Xeo crispy and good but the fillings a bit on the bland side.  The place was a delight.
author: Jan Y.

description: Worst Vietnamese food I have had. Bad quality meat to where pho ga is inedible and banh xeo had nothing inside.  Def not going back EVER!!
author: Margaret L.

description:
[03/17/2012, 4:00pm]

To preface this review, I have been on the hunt for good Banh Beo ever since I moved to the Bay Area. After trying their Banh Beo, I'm still searching. 

I came here on a Saturday afternoon. I ordered banh beo to go and waited about 20 minutes for them to make it. I was looking back into the kitchen to see if they were going to make it fresh, but they just microwaved some pre-made banh beo. The cakes were too thick, there wasn't very much toppings. It was okay, but not great. After failing to find good banh beo again, and paying $6 for 5 cakes, I determined that when I go to Vietnam this summer I'm going to learn how to make it myself. 

But, everyone who was in the restaurant looked pretty happy. Most people were eating soup. I might come back to try the Bun Rieu.
author: Michele E.

description: This is the best vietnamese restaurant in SF.  No doubt about it.  I have been coming here for over 6 years, even back before when it was Ngoc Mai!  Best/authentic Bun Bo Hue in the city.  The atmosphere is homey, and the food speaks for itself.  I have never been disappointed in anything that Ive ordered.  Also love that they are open early - why wait in line for brunch at some garbage overpriced SF restaurant when you can go to tuyet mai for the most delicious food ever?!?!
author: CC C.

description:
Was taken here the other day with the assertion that Ngoc Mai had legit bun bo hue. While overall the meal was satisfying and adequately filled me up, I can't say that I would agree with the reputation that Ngoc Mai has for its bun bo hue.

The bun bo hue was minimally flavorful and really not all that authentic. For starters, they didn't serve any cabbage with their side dish. Secondly, the meat wasn't what you would find in a typical bowl. Sliced pork? What the? Also, the notion that bun bo hue is supposed to be at least a tad bit spicy? Didn't feel it here. Lastly, a large bowl will set you back $9 (with tax). Seriously?

I'd probably give Ngoc Mai a lower rating if not for the fact that eating there reminded me - for the first time since moving away from Socal - of dining in those dirty hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese places in the Little Saigon district in Orange County. Whether that's a good thing or not, well ... home is where the heart is right? 2.5 stars.
author: Tom P.

description:
Ngoc Mai is one of the best, if not the best, bun bo hue restaurants in the city. It's a ghetto hole-in-the-wall that helps to deliver an authentic Vietnam experience in the heart of the 'Loin.

The bun xeo is very well made, with a perfect crisp to the crepe. The #2 noodle soup (crab, pig's feet, & shrimp noodles) is really good -- piping hot with tons of fresh shrimp flavor. I do wish they gave a bigger piece of pig's feet, but all in all, the noodle soup is perfect for a freezing cold day in SF.

The cream of the crop, however, is Ngoc Mai's bun bo hue. The flavors and ingredients of the spicy noodle soup are the best I've had among all the bun bo hue joints in the city. 

This is a truly awesome experience for authentic Vietnamese street food.
author: Roy C.

description: Cute little mom n pop place in the tenderloin. The bun bo hue is the best I've had in SF. I haven't really tried anything else on their menu but when I crave a spicy noodle soup I come here for the bun bo hue. My only complaint is that they could have more convenient hours.
author: Mai C.

description:
I am REALLY REALLY sad to say that...

The last time I went here with a bun bo hue craving...I left unsatisfied.  

My heart broke when I took my first bite.  My friend told me that the taste had changed...but I didn't/couldn't believe her.

I guess good things don't last...
author: nancy b.

description:
Never had Hue Pho before... so decided to try it.

The Bun bo hue was amazing! Maybe it's because I've never had it, but I like it.

The spiciness, the pigs blood, all of it adds to the taste.
author: Vincent W.

description:
I usually don't really have cravings for Vietnamese noodle soup.  I mean, I love noodle soup, but like not the kind of cravings when I think about it, i drool....

Oh Ngoc Mai... The bf introduced me to Ngoc Mai for their spicy #1 soup noodle bowl cuz I said I love noodle soup.  This mysterious literally hole in the wall offers LOTSA interesting dishes, but i went with his recommendation of the #1 bowl.

So the soup noodle came, I took a sip of the soup.  mMmm what did they put in there... sooo... TASTY!  Not spicy initially, but as i kept eating, and eating, the spicy-ness kicked in like turbo... HOT HOT HOT, but SOOOO TASTY... oh please god.... allow me to have the power to take another bite... even though my tongue is burning like crazy... just one more sip of the soup... is all i ask for....

And then we left the restaurant, and I asked the bf for the name... and he said HE DOESN'T KNOW??!!!  he just kinda know how to get there!!  So my birthday came, he asked me what I want for lunch, I SAID SPICY NOODLE SOUP and that would make me the happiest woman in the world... and this time, I make sure I know the name of this place where they offer heavenly tasty spicy noodle soup... mmmMmm my favorite!
author: Gigi T.

description:
Small little restaurant- the dining area is maybe the size of my bedroom!

I didnt really like the pho here. I ordered the beef noodles which came with meatballs: the broth was just warm and not that tasty; the noodles were too soft; and portion was pretty small compared to other places; the beef wasn't what I expected either. We also ordered eggrolls that came out way too greasy and just a tad bit warm. The tea was good, though.
author: M W.

description: Great food with warm home-y service! Tried Banh Xeo the first time here and it was delicious. The server graciously showed us how to eat it - and accurately described it as messy but it was still fun to try something new. Also had the Bun Bo Hue which was very flavorful. I'd definitely go again.
author: crystal y.

description: If you are looking for some good bun rieu or bun bo hue without breaking your bank then this is the place to go. This is a small place but its a good one. Located in the TL, the area can be a little shady but nothing will 'happen' to you. The broth here is really done right and they also put all the right ingredients with it like the pigs blood, ham hock and beef brisket. I do wish the portions were a bit bigger because a 'large' wasn't really that large in my opinion. I usually have to get some egg/spring rolls on the side so that I'm full. Another good thing is that, the daughter (i'm assuming she is) of the owners is the waitress so it's much easier to order and  give specifics to someone who knows perfect english.
author: edward k.

description:
Cheap, healthy, tasty food!

I lived in San Jose and then Orange County in the past and so far, Ngoc Mai has the best Com Tam Bi Cha, Bun Bo Hue, Bun Bo Xao, and others. They are located in Tenderloin and it's not a best neighborhood in the city but I do feel warm and cozy each time I dine there, the food is fresh and organic as it can be and I NEVER experience the side effect of MSG...unlike some other Vietnamese restaurants in the city. On the topic of MSG and unsanitary food, I lived in the city for 5 years now and as a daily diner, I had my more than fair share of food that overdosed with MSG, uncleaned and required Pepto Bismol, Pepcid AC for desserts. Ngoc Mai is a blessing in the sky for my stomach, no longer I worry about MSG and fear of getting sick...thanks Ngoc Mai.

Overall, this is my home away from home type of restaurant, I try to go there everyday if I could despite a long long walk back uphill to my apt in Nob Hill...and yes, they do close at 6 pm everyday and that's the only drawback.
author: Dennis P.

description:
The "Light" switch is to the right when you enter the loo.

Really 1-1/2 stars, but weighted.

I really wanted to like this place. It had a lot of promise.  The place is clean and the staff is friendly. The tile walls and compact size allowed me to momentarily imagine I had been transported to The Netherlands.

I am technically on a quest for Bún bò Hu, but I saw "Duck Curry Noodle Soup" on the menu and had to try that. The broth, the spiciness and the portion were acceptable. But, the duck (have I mentioned that I have a thing for duck prepared in Asian restaurants?) was awful -- not offal -- awful.

The tea that was delivered to the table when we arrived tasted as if it had been brewed in a giant vinyl urn that had never been cleaned. The Vietnamese Coffie I ordered was a generous portion, but thin and flavorless.

A dining companion ordered shrimp rolls which were unremarkable. (I guess that is a compliment in comparison.)

My dining companions reported that their meals were also unsatisfying.

If this were the only Vietnamese restaurant within 50 miles of my home, I might eat there again.

It is not.
author: BigJohnS F.

description: Awesome Vietnamese place! The Banh Xeo is soooo good (but very messy) - must try if you like banh xeo. I got a lemongrass pork bun noodles and I forgot what my friends got but it was their first time having legit Vietnamese and they LOVED it. Gem of a place!
author: Melissa Y.

description: banh bot loc is a thing of glory.
author: Donald C.

description: Super friendly service. Wide selection. Everything we had was pretty legit. Banh khot is great. Nice and crispy. This place transports you straight to Viet Nam from the laced aqua window shades right down the to down tiles.
author: CAM T.

description:
I've been on the hunt for banh beo since my introduction in Orange County.  I've even tried making it at home but it takes too long and someone, meaning me, has to do all those dishes.

This is the only place in in San Francisco that has banh beo.  It satisfied my craving but it's nothing like my first taste of this salty sweet steamed rice dish.  Oh how I crave orange county vietnamese food.

I would only come back for the banh beo.  The pho left me parched for hours and i smelled of fish sauce.
author: Jeanne C.

description: This place has got one of the best restaurant bun bo hue I have ever had. It is not homemade but damn it can't get better than this anywhere else. If you are coming in for a decor don't bother because you won't get that here but if you want some good hangover noodle soup this is the place to be.
author: Allison T.

description: Delicious, relatively cheap food with an extensive menu in the Tenderloin. The interior of the restaurant is very charming and the service is great. Only downside is that it's open from 10 to 6, so you'll have to find dinner elsewhere.
author: Kate P.

description: Straight up hungover after a recent Irish holiday. Craving some warm broth to soothe the pain. Came for the Bun Bo Hue. Excellent. Spicy, seasoned broth with tender beef and cha. Don't forget the bean sprouts and mint. Hit the spot on the head. Love me this little family run spot. $9 for a LARGE bowl.
author: Anthony R.

description: Mediocre place for bbh! Had the bun mang vit which was ok as well. Didn't like going through duck bones while slurping soup! I would come back next time for the Banh khot! It is delicious! Mini crepe with shrimp that Has a smoky flavor to it!mmm
author: Nancy T.

description: They have reopened under a new name in the same location with a slightly expanded menu, quite a bit more vegetarian options. Same owners and chefs.
author: Anne H.

description: Friendly service, big portions for the price. Lunch less than $10 = score! I ordered a large Bun Rieu, aka crab and shrimp tomato soup with rice noodles for $8! It was delicious. I finished it all.
author: Teresa H.

description: Great hole in the wall restaurant. Bun Bo Hue and Banh Xeo are AMAZING!! The price is pretty typical, but the quality of the food is great and the service is very nice and quick. Definitely recommend it over the more pricey viet restaurants in the TL
author: Kevin L.

description: Eating here is great because the food is fantastic and you are truly supporting a family business. This is as close to eating from a Vietnamese family's kitchen as you can get. They use home appliances and run a small kitchen but produce very high quality, homemade meals. The beef stew was excellent with tons of flavor. What caught my eye was the attention to detail. Typical beef stews throws in chunks of carrots while Ngoc Mai carefully dices it into bite size cubes. Beef and tendons were well stewed and tender. Other menu items look quite authentic and delicious. Service is a little slow due to only one waiter but totally understand the nature of the business. This is a jewel in the Tenderloin.
author: Ed L.

description: Decent bun bo hue; if you're looking for BBH in the 'loin, look no further.  This is your spot.  I did have a few issues with it, but I can overlook them because it's much harder to find the right soup than the right meat.  My gripes are that the pork meat was pretty much inedible - flavorless and tough to chew.  However, their slices of beef were the opposite.  Their well-seasoned and tender beef bumped what would've been three stars to four.  I would recommend skipping the pork meat when ordering.  The other thing, which also doesn't bother me too much, is that you only get bean sprouts, and no cabbage.
author: Erika C.

description: Their soup is really delicious.  Nice service too.  Don't let the simple decor fool you, great food to be had.
author: Tom W.

description:
I have been looking all over SF for a place that has good Bun Bo Hue so that I don't have to drive all the way down to SJ to get it from Ca Mau.

The store is very small and seats only about 26 people so if you go during lunch hours it can get full real quick. The soup they use for the Bun Bo Hue is very tasty and doesn't leave much to ask for. However the meat to noodle ratio could be better (more meat and less noodle). Everything that's expected to be in bun bo hue is in there, but only has a small piece of pig feet. That being said the overall bowl is still delicious and filling and it is probably for the better that I have a smaller piece of pig feet anyways. =)
author: Jerry J.

description:
My wife likes their bum bo hue
the place is cozy and the service good
very family style
author: Ron A.

description: It was good pho, the broth was delectable and the noodles were just thin and delicious. The service was good, the prices are decent, nothing to complain about the entire place. It's a nice little quiet place in the TL that's delicious.
author: Rohan D.

description: Yummy, yummy. The Bun Bo Hue is just so tasty and I don't often order this since a lot of the places I've gone to the soup is greasy and the noodles are not fresh.  The meat in this soup are not fried, the soup tastes fresh, and the small bowl was just a perfect size for me.  This is a great find.
author: Jean M.

description: This place is amazing!!! Little worried that it wouldn't be good being that I was going to the TL. This place is a must, Yes it's small but the service is great! I loved the Fresh Lemonade it was really tasty. I also got the chicken chow mien which came with peanuts, I was surprised that it came with peanuts being that it didn't say that on the menu. I told them I had a peanut allergy and they remade my dish and it was very very yummy. I definitely would go back.
author: Veronica V.

description:
This is really a 4.5 star review but since half stars aren't available and I'm not the type to round up when provided such a narrow 5 point margin, I'll give it a solid 4 stars.

This place really feels very comfortable.  The storefront's aged and homey, like someplace in south Vietnam.  It's a small family style restaurant; a place that has no table seat under 4 people, with two long picnic style tables in the center.  A half door leads to the kitchen area on the left when you enter, so if you're friendly enough you can simply tell the cook what you want yourself.

i've only eaten my signature meal here one time, (pho tai nam/gau with steak on the side and a lemonade) but the beef was fresh and very tasty.  The broth, albeit a bit watery, had a nice kick of white pepper and a lot of home-style original flavors-- the star anise really was noticeable, while lighter flavors of licorices and cumin took a pleasant stance off to the wayside of center stage.  A lot of Vietnamese places forgo using licorice altogether, so that by itself warrants this place a 4 star review at the least. I think Ngoc in Vietnamese means water so the name of the restaurant suits their pho broth fittingly. Very light and clean with no added msg. It rivals my wife's pho broth.  Adding lime juice and garlic-chili pepper oil mix like I normally do actually ruined it a bit.

So why the half star? The service was really really refreshing.  For some reason, most of the places where I go, the person who serves you looks and acts like they just lost a fight that involved a yelling contest. The woman who served me was very pleasant and attentive and even had sense enough as a server to ask if I wanted ice water or hot tea.  Going by the conversation the other patrons where having, the Bun Bo Hue is their signature meal to try.

Why not a 5 star review?  Although I know they have it if I had asked for it (since it was available in other dishes on the menu), pho with brisket or flank was not on the menu.  This place is also just a TAD on the expensive side, at 10.00 for a regular bowl with extra meat. Also, a side bowl of hot broth for steak on the side orders was not provided.
author: Rich H.

description:
It's not you, it's very likely me.

I jumped when I saw steamed chicken on the menu, and excitement turned to disappointment when I got home and realized it was mostly bone, some white meat, but mostly dark and a layer of fat on each piece. And a lot of rice. Someone in need at the corner down the street received quite a meal.

Reading other yelps has left me thinking I probably should have gone with soup. Regardless, my minimal knowledge of ordering vietnamese doesn't leave me very qualified to say whether what I got was good, bad or par for the course. Not much money was spent, people were friendly, we'll chalk it up to a learning and go with three stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
Oh my God This has to be the best place to get Bun Bo Hue in the city, or northern part of the bay area for that matter. I first came to this place in 2002 with a co-worker, where he introduced me to my first bowl of Bun Bo Hue ever. I haven't found a better place since. 

I would describe this place as a good place to go to cure a hangover, quick fast and cheap with an extremely authentic taste to their soups.
I have tried the pho bowl here but it isn't their best thing on the menu by far. 

I have tried all of the appetizers and they are all decent. If you like a spicy noodle bowl, then this is the place to give a try if you are in the T.L. Ignore the hobos and bum-fights, enjoy a quick bowl of noodle soup, and get the heck outta the hood happily =D 

Cash-only but prices are wallet and purse friendly!
author: Dave K.

description: What a hidden gem in the ghettos!  The place is relatively small but the service is excellent.  The waitress was very nice.  I was able to replace the type of noodles I want in my bun bo hue.  It was my first time having bun bo hue and I REALLY enjoyed the soup base.  I am all for flavorful and delicious soup base.  But I did not really dig the meat they served in bun bo hue.  If I could, I would incorporate some beef brisket slices, beef tripe, and lots of pig's blood but then it would not be bun bo hue... The portions are decent in size; the large size was way too big for me, I thought I might be able to finish it since I was pretty hungry.  Next time, I will just order a small! Anyways, the noodles took a little longer to come because there was only one chef in the kitchen.  Nevertheless, the wait is worth it.  If you are in  hurry, probably best to pre-order.
author: Ann L.

description:
Sunday morning, not hung over but certainly not well adjusted to the world nor thinking any variety of fuzzy thoughts, I found this small joint little more than a block from my place. Note to self: venture south more often, young (lazy) man. Jesus.

Dear Ngoc Mai: who makes your stock and can I enter into their sacred tutelage? How do you achieve such perfection? I had bun bo hue with lemongrass and chicken, and the combination of fresh poultry flavor, subtle citrus, light chili spice, and the perfect hint of sweetness caught me woefully off guard. Light but assertive, I'll admit, I kinda...almost...swooned. Today I went back, and had duck curry noodle soup...once again you can put garbage in broth this good and it becomes magic. The banh xeo, by the way: exceptional. Three varieties of herbal garnish. Plus: a big pot of solid red tea. You get rehydrated, refreshed, rejuvenated.

It's a small restaurant, tackily decorated in the extreme but this is charming. Service is friendly and prices excellent. Give it a try, it's special.
author: Peter B.

description:
Awesome Hue food in this tiny place in the TL. I tried the bun Bo hue and the broth was very clean, deep beef stock with a background of lemongrass and slight kick from chili oil and chili flakes. The noodles were good and the beef/pork slices tender. Very nice bowl that hit the spot. Not as good as BBH An Nam, but likely the best in the City.

The banh xeo was tasty and crispy, served with herbs n greens as fresh as can be. 

The presumed daughter mother team are the sweetest.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I am an idiot.  

I'm a frequent diner here and one time a few weeks ago, I strolled in right before they closed assuming they accepted card payments.  Well after my delicious meal of..banh xeo and banh canh gio heo (#2), I tried to pay with plastic and they nicely said, "sorry sister, only cash!"   

.......UH.OH.  I could feel the embarassment creeping over me.  Except, the woman was SO understanding and said "It's OK, next time you come in, pay, no worry!"  Now, THAT is an example of how home-y this restaurant is. 

That being said..I don't really like the bun bo hue or bun rieu.  Maybe I'm weird because everyone else seems to like it.  I just found it a little bland.  I LOVE THE BANH XEO THOUGH, as messy as it is to eat (imo).  I don't know how to wrap stuff in veggies, dip it in fish sauce, balance the pungent liquid and get it to my mouth without at least splattering a little.  But that's ok, because this isn't a froo froo place and paper tablemats are replaceable.  So paper tablemats and all, I would say the cleanliness of this place is better than your average pho-joint.

So far I've tried #1, #2, #3 (all hue specialties), saw someone else get #12 (Ngoc Mai dry noodle combo something something), tried thit kho, ca kho to (catfish in caramel sauce), as well as a couple of things on the menu that my co-diner and I requested.  I've really loved everything, but I think the 1 + 3 were a tad hyped up by yelp reviews.  The portions here aren't HUGE, but more like..home-sized.  Yeah, that's the charm of Ngoc Mai, I think.  It's just homey-good-food that doesn't make you FEEL like you dined out.  Prices are homie prices too =P
author: Tokki M.

description: I was beyond hung over and needed something to cure it. My friend suggested this place, I never heard of it but noodle soup sounded good. Bun Bo Hue is what she suggested I couldn't think so I said ok whatever order it. I saw a crispy crepe looking thing on someone else table and I pointed and said I want that too! The crispy crepe was so yummy! My friend said I had to wrap it in lettuce then dip it in the fish sauce, perfection. The Bun Bo Hue was very authentic tasting, lots of flavor, lots of ingredients and noodles. Digging through I see blood chunks, GROSS!! I gave those chunks to my friend. The waitress was very nice and she didn't make me feel bad when I went to the restroom many times during me time there ha! the place was small so it was a bit embarassing, sorry TMI.
author: Karen T.

description:
Feel bad about writing this because the service was super nice,  I thought I hit the jackpot after reading the bun rieu reviews, but it was more like buying a $50 scratchcard with zero matches.

Bun rieu is a tomato based broth with vermicelli noodles and huge clumps of crab.  Eggs are used to keep the crab mixture together, but my bowl only had egg, NO CRAB!  Total disappointment.  B's bun bo hue (beef stock stoup with rice stick noodles, slices of meat) was decent.  Nice broth, but can't compare to Cau Mau or Bun Bo An Nam in SJ.  

They did have an extensive menu and I'm sure they're great at other dishes.  A nice selection of central Viet dishes.  Looks like it's been around forever, so they must do something right.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
This is what Jessica H. told me about Ngoc Mai before we left for lunch:  "This is like total total dive.  So get ready...they cook everything in dirt."  Mmmm dirt...way to sell it Jess.

There are about 150 things on the menu and nothing is priced over $7.50, which I like.  In fact, even with tax and an appetizer I still only paid $9.  I had the #3 Bun Rieu (sans blood cubes) which is the Noodle Soup with crab meat and fried tofu.  It was delicious.  Apparently it's usually a brighter red color and there's more crab meat, but I was still impressed.  

The Shrimp Cupcakes we got were really tasty too.  For $6.00 you get 8 fried crepes filled with custardy filling and topped with a shrimp.  Watch out cause they're super greasy though...like I bit into it and I felt grease trickle down my chin.

All in all the food was pretty delicious and worth short cab ride...especially seeing Evan L. and his long legs scrunched up into the front seat of the car, knees up to his chin while I lounged behind him with a good 2 feet of space, that in itself was worth the ride.  Srsly.
author: Katherine C.

description:
The restaurant's tiles makes me feel like I'm eating inside of a bathroom. Nothing fancy here - just cheap, Viet goodness.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
I would say, this place serves some of the best Bun Bo Hua in the city. When I stepped in, I felt as if I entered some sort of twilight zone because it felt as if I was really in Vietnam (even though I've never been there!). I felt pretty cozy and relaxed while eating in here. 

They also have alot of Authentic Vietnamese appetizers and snacks. I haven't had the chance to try them all, but I'll be sure to just order appetizers the next time I dine here. 

But beware, there are always a bunch of crack heads lurking around the corners. 

And to Mobile B., check out Turtle Tower down the block for their Pho Ga... this place makes a mean Bun Bo Hua and Bun Rieu.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I am a die hard Ngoc Mai fan, uber fan, fanatic! I crave for their delicious noodle soup all the time. 

Breakfast: I should have some noodle soup to start my day with.
Lunch: Yeah, I think noodle soup will hold me over 
Dinner: Honey, how about some noodle soup tonight?
Late night Snack: I'll just have a small bowl of noodle soup, ya know, it is getting late and I am about to go to bed. 
Sleep talking in Bed: Noodles, Noodles, Noodles..zz..Soup, soup,soup

So you can imagine my love for this place.. I like to start with the Banh Xieo and then work my way to their Bun Bo Hue, followed by The Boyfriend's Bun Rieu (that is when he's in the bathroom or I have just created some type of diversion "Hey, look over there" -slurp-slurp) 

I have contemplated about bringing a dummy or mannequin to the table just so I don't look like a complete fatty pig ordering three dishes when I am alone. More food and less of a challenge to fight over my Ngoc Mai's noodle soup. HmmMMmMm..
author: H To The W.

description:
There is only one reason for me to go to Ngoc Mai and that is for the #3, Bun Rieu.  Their crepes are also great, with the right texture and crunch.   I really can't comment on the rest of their menu which I find is subpar compared to their #3.   Also, everything is made to order so it's super easy to order almost everything without cilantro!  Score!

My only real complaint about this place is that they close early (considering the sketchy people that hang out on that corner, I can't really blame them) and they always take a month off every year for vacation.  Of course, it's always during a time I'm craving Bun Rieu.

For good pho ga, I prefer Turtle Tower.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
This is one of the more authentic Vietnamese restaurants I've found in the city.  It's a dirty, hole in the wall place, equipped with outdated furniture and tableware, which really just adds to the authenticity of the place.  You really do feel like you just stepped out of the TL and into Vietnam, but without the unbearable heat and having to eat your sweat as it drips into your food because you know that even if you were to wipe it, it would start dripping again and any extra movement in this kind of heat is really unnecessary.

This place offers a variety of genuine Vietnamese dishes that you usually don't find anywhere else, however, the only thing I order here is the Bun Bo Hue which is a spicy beef noodle soup.  Rarely will you find this item in any restaurant and even if you should be so lucky, it will never taste as good as this place.  They have this dish down.  A warning though, if coagulated pig blood cubes and pig feet aren't your thing, then pass on it.
author: Kim K.

description: They close superrr early. Tried to come here once for an early 6:30 dinner and they were closed. Good thing I was in a car cuz it's not a real friendly neighborhood! Finally had a chance to eat Bun Bo Hue for lunch another day. Met up some friends during work and it was pretty good. I think I'd like An Nam more, but this is way closer. They don't give cabbage either. I hate that they close at 6pm though!!
author: Wendy L.

description:
Hands down, this is by far the most authentic Vietnamese restaurant in the city, period!  I used to live 2 blocks away (yes, I'm gangster like that) and have had most things on the menu, and have always had a good-tasting meal, and the food is damn cheap too! They specialize in central VN cuisine, and even the national dishes like Com Suong Nuong (my favorite, which is pork chops with rice) have a central twist to them, which I really like. 

The mother always asks how I'm doing and ask how schools going when I was still an undergrad, which I thought was really sweet of her. One time I came in way after the lunch rush a little before 3pm, and the whole family was eating and the mother invited me to sit at the same table. They're really nice people.

My little sister really likes this place too, though her favorite is the Bun Bo Hue (Hue-style beef noodle soup). I really can't think of a better place to eat lunch at, but Vietnamese is naturally my favorite cuisine, so don't take my word for it.
author: Joseph P.

description: I adore this place. The owner's are very sweet and gracious. I go here for their bun bo hue. I know what people are saying, that the bun bo hue doesn't seem authentic. It's not like most bun bo hue's I've had either, but to me it's a delicious rendition. I feel like it has a fresh homemade flavor. Their bbh hits the spot every time, it makes me feel happy.
author: Sara B.

description:
This place started off so promising.  With its tiled walls, fluorescent lighting (well not entirely positive as it was the middle of sunny day, but I imagine it probably was), various knick knacks on the wall, and kitchen tucked in the back, this place had the look and smells of a place you may very well find in 'Nam. Okay, well I've never been to Vietnam. But I have eaten at places that looked like this in other parts of Asia, so I am imagining it is what a restaurant over there could look like.

The menu (which oddly looks like a DVD case) has a large number of selections. I settled on some known constants for comparison: pho ga and bahn xeo. 

The pho ga was mediocre at best.  The broth was light and slightly sweet. Some of the noodles were mottled with a strange color. The chicken was slightly dry. In the end, the broth proved to be too light and sweet for my tastes. I did not even finish it.

The bahn xeo was also a bit of a disappointment. The crepe was completely crispy (not light and airy on the inside) and incredibly oily. Cutting through it literally shattered the pancake. The filling was also relatively flavorless.

If you're into the Vietnamese iced coffee that is dripped ... this is not the place for you. It's mixed behind the counter from pre-made coffee.

On the upside, the people working there are incredibly nice.
author: Mobile B.

description: 5 stars for staying consistently good! This is my go-to for Vietnamese food. Why, out of all the other Viet places in the Tenderloin? Well 1) it's an awesome mom and pops place, 2) service is fast, and 3) food is homemade! Only negative is the business hours - why close at 6pm (dinner time)?!?
author: Phuc N.

description: This is usually my first go to spot if i'm ever in the city for some bun bo hue.  Service is excellent and food is on point.
author: Cedric F.

description:
This place provides decent Vietnamese food.  The price is really cheap, you can get decent lunch for about 6 to 7 bucks.  Bun bo hue is not bad, I wish that they would give me extra other kinds of veggies beside just bean sprouts and chopped lettuce.   They have pretty good Central Vietnames (Hue) food like banh beo, banh xeo, cha tom

Here is my list of favorites:
* Bun Bo Hue (spicy beef noodles soup)
* Bun rieu (tomato broth noodles)
* Banh canh (udon style noodles)
* Banh beo (white rice cakes those comes in small bowls)
* Banh xeo (crepes, got to try this, it comes with a big fresh veggies place that you can wrap with the crepes)
author: Lily K.

description:
I like this little place a lot.  The people were nice and the food was good.


Go to the potty before you get here - but only because to get to the bathroom, you have to work your way around the table in the back and hang your ass over a table to move out of the way for the door swing.

SF is great for little restaurants shoehorned in little spaces.
Wheel chairs unadvised, but I would order takeout from this place if I lived nearer it.
author: RiCH K.

description:
this is the kind of place that i walk by and actually notice.  small hole in the wall with an extensive menu.  ordered banh xeo. ~$6.50
you can tell they have expert skill in making these with their perfect shape.  crispy, slightly coconutty crepe flavor, with lots of fresh lettuce, mint, and balanced good fish sauce.  this feels like home cooking in a restaurant form.  one negative about the banh xeo is that they don't peel the shrimp all the way!!  please remove all the shell and tail!!
author: Rob C.

description: I was looking for really good bun bo hue and I read that this was the best place to have it in SF.  It did not disappoint.  Very yummy.  Had the right meats in it, good amount of spiciness, could have used just a tad more noodles, but really good.  And the atmosphere is very old school, like it.  Also had the Vietnamese coffee, not great, but next time I will just stick to the BBH!
author: Jeff T.

description: Ngoc Mai is the true definition of a family-run hole-in-the-wall business. After reading the reviews, I was a bit skeptical about the hole-in-the-wall descriptions, but the seating inside wasn't too bad. You just have to make sure you go early enough for a seat. Otherwise prepared to be waiting outside for awhile as there is only one person who is the waitress, server and cleans all the tables. Inside you'll be able to see the kitchen where the rest of the family operates between 2-3 refrigerators full of individually prepared meats and veggies that were pre-cut and stored for cooking. The noodles there are fantastic - you can request what type you like (wide rice noodles, thin rice noodles, egg noodles, etc) so make sure you ask for the kind you prefer. The beef noodle soup had a fantastic homemade taste and the lighter (by comparison) bun rue was full of crab and tomatoes.YUM!!! A great meal after a night out or just to warm you up during the cooler days in SF!
author: Angela S.

description:
Bun Bo Hue is my favorite vietnamese dish/bowl and after moving from So-Cal, Westminster, home of Little Saigon to the city. I've been on the search to find a place that can satisfy me and come close to my mommas homemade Bun Bo Hue. I feel like i've tried every place in the TL that yelp has suggested and every place seems to serve Bun Bo Hue differentely. 

I came here with the bf last week around 2pm on a monday. Parking was easy, there's 2hr free parking in the front. The place was empty, missing the lunch crowed i assume. The menu is quite large here but the one thing i was here was for their Bun Bo Hue. #1 i believe. We ordered 2 bowls extra spicy. (after reading yelp reviews i remembered some ppl saying its not that spicy so ask for extra spicy). Waited maybe about 10 minutes and we were served. The bowl was large but where was all the noodles? and no cabbage? The broth was some what ok. It lacks the aroma taste of lemongrass and the the sweetness of the broth. Something just wasn't right and we left hungry and disappointed. The price seems reasonable i think it less than $7 a bowl but not enough food or at least for us not enough noodles. I don't think i'll be back, the food and service did not impress me to try it again. My hunt will continue..
author: Jacinta D.

description:
Having recently been introduced to Banh Xeo, the Vietnamese crepes, I was looking forward to having one again. After consultation with a Vietnamese person, I was steered to Ngoc Mai. When I found myself in the area, decided to give it a try. 
Now, where I ate the Banh Xeo prior to this occasion was at the Slanted Door, which is definitely a different scene from this little hole in the wall. Guess i was expecting to be blown away by the much more authentic version, but sadly, that was not the case. The crepe was not uniformly crispy, the shrimp still had their tails on, and the rest of the innards, though tasty were not what I had been hoping for.
Did not try anything else, though I could see the noodles in the pho were of the broader variety, leading me to think perhaps this was Northern Vietnam style, and perhaps that accounted for the difference in the crepe?
The service was pleasant and efficient, and I would give it another try should I be in the area.
author: Carla B.

description: Woohoo! I'm slowly eating my way through the Vietnamese restaurants in the TL, but this one is definitely going on that favorite list for cheap and delicious food. Fresh bun, extremely flavorful soups - go, go, go!
author: Sonja L.

description: The older woman who works there is really friendly, always smiling. She gives you the whole can along with the full glass when you order plum soda. Come here for the Bun Bo Hue, it's delicious, and the home made fish cakes are a nice plus to an already tasty dish. I don't think they take card, so have cash handy! They close early too, which is a bummer. Also it's a very "cozy" space so it might be best to go with a small group of people.
author: Susan K.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!  It's one of my most favorite restaurants in the city.  The Bun Bo Hue is sooo yummy and I love the banh khot here as well.  The people here are so friendly.  Definitely worth your time and money!
author: Cathy L.

description: came here to try their bun bo hue, and it was comparable to the good ones in SJ.  I really like the broth, the fragrant and flavor is really good!  will come back again!
author: Candy C.

description: This review is for their banh beo. Short and to the point, they were okay, but lacking that extra something that makes me want to go back for more.  Sadly, this place is just a few blocks from where I live and I'm always craving banh beo, but I won't be back for those.  I'd go back to try something else though.
author: ML N.

description: on one hadn, i want to give them another try, as i feel this many people can't be wrong about this place having the best bun bo hue. maybe it was because we got there around closing. but i just don't care that much.
author: Mark A.

description:
Now this is bún bò Hue the way it was meant to be.  The lady cooking who also took my order was very nice and didn't make a shocked face when I confirmed I did want "everything."   Spicy, not overly oily, the right kind of noodles, all the right cuts of meat, and the blood--as someone who is not Vietnamese, I can not emphasize how much I appreciate actually being served what I order.  Good to the last spoonful.

I won't say I wish I lived within walking distance though because it's the Tenderloin.  If I'm ever in the area, I will definitely return for a bowl.
author: Christina G.

description: OMG.....i love their spicy pig feet noodle (bun bo hue) even though there is not much spice to it, it is surprisingly tasty for a hole in a wall Vietnamese joint. My boyfriend brought me here one day and right when we parked the car, i asked him where is the restaurant? He laughed and said right there and pointed at a house looking place. I was very surprised of the space they used to make it into a restaurant but i must say, everything on their menu is GOOD! The shredded pork roll comes with a very different sweet fish sauce that i cannot get anywhere else. If i could, I would buy a whole jug from them. (YES it is that good)
author: Sophie L.

description: Just went to this place on Sunday for lunch. Its a quint place, small, folks are nice. Food quite good. I had the Duck Noodle soup. Unlike other places that gives you a Peking Duck leg, this place gives you an actual duck leg braised - yummy.
author: Johnson H.

description: Where else in the city can you find Bun Bo Hue that is actually good. I been coming here for over 15 years and 90% of what I get is the NUMBER 1 BUN BO HUE. I've been all around Frisco tasting Bun Bo Hue and they are all garbage compared to this spot. The Pho sucks here but thats probably why its not their #1. If you are looking for pho, go somewhere else. The family owned biz are eager to please. Very nice family. If you go in here, you will see most people eating a #1. The hot oil they have on the side of the table is good. I heard they make it themselves. Try the banh xeo (vietnamese crepe). They make it fresh and crispy and is damn good too. Bun Rieu is good too. Place is small and is in the heart of the L's full of crackheads but is worth the visit every time. 5 stars just because its the only place that has the best Bun Bo Hue in S.F. Good luck trying to find one as good in Frisco.
author: Vinh T.

description:
this is one of the most "keeping it real" vietnamese digs in SF.  i have tried a half dozen or so dishes, ranging from Pho, to Bun Bo Hue, to Bun Rieu to Banh Xeo and a handful of others.

a great barometer in judging a cheap vietnamese restaurant is to see how well stocked the "green side dish" is.  it should have fresh bean sprouts, basil thai mint, sawleaf herb, lime (not lemon) and sometimes cilantro (depending on your entree).  most vietnamese places i've been to in The City generally lack one or more of these ingredients, and aren't always that fresh.  Ngoc Mai scores an "A+" in this mark.

If you don't like the food here, then you probably don't like vietnamese food.  it's not necessarily the restaurant's fault.  every dish i've had is pretty darn close to how "mama does it".  and you know, that's how it "should be done".

Service is pretty good, generally the folks here nice people.  the decor is so-so, nothing fancy, but nothing too "divey" either.  its appearance won't knock you out, but it probably won't deter you either.

5 stars for food.
-1 star for day time only hours (no evenings)
+1 star for authenticity.
author: vuForce Fresh n.

description: This little Vietnamese restaurant rocks!!! I visited from LA and was looking for a place with homemade style Vietnamese crepe. This place has that. For noodles, they have really good noodles that are from the Northern part of Vietnam: Bun Rieu and Bun Bo Heu. Authentic flavors!! But I was a little disappointed with their Mi Quang. My Dad was born in Da Nang. I spent almost half of my childhood there. So I KNOW what Mi Quang is. The Mi Quang that they have are like like...not mi quang. little disappointed, but this place deserves a five-star just for the other foods.
author: P. V.

description:
This little hole in the wall is only a block down and around the corner from where I live so I am amazed I never have visited it before today.  A friend was in the mood for Vietnamese food and we both decided to try this new (for both of us) place.  We found the outside very non-discript, almost missing it, and the inside very small but clean and full of Vietnamese patrons which we took as a good sign!  We both ordered a version of Pho.  My friend got duck and I got shrimp with pig's foot.  His was loaded with duck but I couldn't find any pig in mine, although we both got a congealed square of pig blood in our soup which was yummy.  Mine did have a lot of shrimp and other goodies and the waitress loaded a plate with fresh mint, bean sprouts, and limes for our soups.  We also split an appitizer of fresh spring rolls (and gave each of us our own little dipping bowls of sauce), and each of us had a yummy iced coffee with sugar and condensed milk.  It tasted very strong and like a coffee milk shake!  The total bill came to $32.02 which we thought, as San Francisco standards go, a bargain.

Will we be back again?  Heck yes, in a heart beat!
author: ruth r.

description:
Wow, this place has the BEST bun bo hue.  I've been to all the bun bo hue restaurants that serve this and trust me it's the best.  Thinking about it right now makes my mouth water.  Perfect seasoning and cooked perfectly.  Their pho is good too.  It's a cute little restaurant owned by a very nice family.  You can tell they're hard working people.

Bathroom needs some work, but it's a whole in the wall restaurant..what do ya expect?

Anyways, would recommend this place.
author: K T.

description: I occasionally have really strong cravings for pho, or any spicy noodle soup really, and in this case I have to have it immediately. This happened to me last Friday, so I walked around the corner to this little gem and had the #1 Bun Bo Hue. Hit the spot. I will mosdef go back to try everything else.
author: Rikki D.

description: I recently had a MAJOR bun rieu craving. Like major. I did a quick Yelp search and this seemed to be the place to go for Bun Rieu so I gathered up a group of my most preppy co-workers to go to the Tenderloin. I figured if anything happened to us I could push the yuppies towards the crackheads and run. Anyway, I was REALLY hoping to like this place and in a lot of ways it's great. The people are really nice and it's really fast service and it's cheap as all hell (hello, nothing under $7.00!!) but sadly the bun rieu did not live up to my expectations. There's barely and crab in it!! And it doesn' t have that yummy shrimp paste flavor that is soooooo addictive. It's the taste of Asia. The bun rieu I got was good but it just wasn't as good as mom's. I guess that might be reaching too high...
author: Cathy T.

description: i have just started eating at this place recently. I would have the say the food here is decent. Sometimes the taste can be kind of off but i would still say its not to the point where its nasty.  The pricing is pretty decent as well.  For people who have not tried nothern vietnamese food you should give this place a try.
author: Art N.

description: Bun bo hue was a bit disappointing, but nevertheless still  better than most of the other places in the city.  What I liked about this hole in the wall restaurant was the selection and the freshness of the food.  The appetizers were great.  I liked the variety and how they have a lot of authentic dishes that other restaurants do not have.  Also, even though the bun was lacking, it still felt home cooked and that gave me a warm feeling.
author: AhLin C.

description: Did this place close down in the past two weeks or so?  I went there Wednesday 2/9/2011 at like 5PM and it was all boarded up with graffiti all over the boards.  I will be sad if they closed down, easily the best Bun Bo Hue anywhere in the bay area
author: Zachary T.

description: Had the craving for Bun Rieu.  Came here.  Not good, broth wasn't savory good, and where's the crab meat? Sure it's cheap here, but again, where's the crab meat?
author: Derek C.

description: Asian hole-in-the-walls get a -20 handicap on the health rating scale so with a score of 86 (wow) Ngoc Mai is clean enough for me.  My first experience today tells me I'll be back for more.  Checked out the Bun Bo Hue and it was spicy enough, sliced meats were delicate, and soup temperature was definitely go-to-the-hospital hot.  Bowl was a bit on the small size but just enough for me.  Lumberjacks will probably need 2 bowls, upside is that you would fit in an appetizer and noodle bowl AND not run to the gym.  $6.50 tax included and smiling service ... I'll be back.  Can't give it 5 stars after 1 experience so look for update
author: Beautiful B.

description: This is homestyle innocence. I had been shopping in Union Square all day so I wanted to balance my life a bit by finding a mom and pop Vietnamese restaurant. I read the reviews and ordered the bun bo hue. It hit the spot as it was a cool 60 degree day in the City.   I'm sweating from the heat of the dish but it was very good.  I appreciated the simple (yet clean) décor - much like other restaurants in current day Vietnam.  It felt very family run. The father was in the kitchen and the server was his daughter. She was very attentive. When she brought out my coffee, she softly asked if it was to my taste or she could adjust it. Her innocent demeanor made me think of someone I'd bring to meet my parents (but that won't happen, realistically). The food was authentic, place was clean, and service was unpretentious. I appreciated very much the home atmosphere. Since this place is small, it really felt like being invited into someone's home for dinner.  A hot bowl of bun bo hue and a Vietnamese coffee = $10.50, not bad for a hot meal on a cool SF day.
author: Hung N.

description: My favorite pho joint in the city. A lot of traditional dishes you won't find at most pho restaurants. Their Bun Rieu (chicken and tomato based soup with crab paste) is excellent.
author: DT l.

description: went there last night with the bf because it happened to be a short walk from my apt, and we were hungry and wandering aimlessly. we shared a beef/rice soup and some kind of shrimp/coconut-curry dish. overall everything was good and cheap, and there were a lot of interesting dishes on the menu. but it wasn't so tasty that i'd choose a return trip over exploring other eateries. the shrimp was pretty overcooked, but the sauce and vegetables were delicious. the soup had waaaay too much MSG, and i probably wouldn't have liked it if i hadn't been in the mood for some nice hot soup. i guess the word to describe our food would be "palatable"
author: Dana D.

description: i'd pitch a tent and live on the corner if it hadn't already been taken by bums, as many times as i come eat here. it's the closest thing to my mom's cooking that i have found since i have left home. the flavors are extremely authentic and it's run by a family who are genuinely easy going and kind. speaking of authentic, sometimes they let their pet roach come out for you to pet, between me and you, i think it might be a different roach each time, cause after i screamed, the father came out and stepped on it. kind of like my gold fish at home, my friends come over but i always tell them that i am great at keeping things alive. my favorite is #1 the bun bo hue, i just order it with the pho noodles and without the pig knuckles and those brown cubes. eating here allows me to get closer to my goal of buying a house in SF.
author: dan T.
